name: Preşedinte. –
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Maria João Rodrigues, on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, on the European Pillar of Social Rights (2016/2095 (INI)) (A8-0391 / 2016).

name: Maria João Rodrigues
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, the European Parliament will adopt today the most important political initiative for developing a social dimension during this legislature, and for giving citizens the means to get control of their lives and restoring trust in the European Union project. The European Parliament wants this to be a central priority in the roadmap for the future of the European Union to be adopted at the next summit in Rome on 25 March. We must put the social dimension at the heart of this roadmap for the future of the European Union.  This European Parliament report is based on very long work by our Members, and also involving many other stakeholders across Europe who were extremely active in building up a new vision for the social dimension of the European Union. So first of all I would like to thank all of you. Now is the moment, once the report is adopted, for the Commission to come also with a bold proposal, to put it on the table at the Council of Ministers, and finally on the table of the European Council. The European Parliament will stand ready to set this deal with the Commission, the Council, and the European Council.  We must have a vision of a social dimension able to cope with the current challenges, which are not only global competition and ageing trends, but also a very important digital revolution, and internal problems and internal divergences in the eurozone. This report must become a turning point when updating social standards and security and fundamental social rights for all European citizens. This pillar should address the entire European Union. First of all, by giving children a real guarantee to avoid poverty; delivering a strong Youth Guarantee; and organising the transition between education and employment in such a way that we make the best of the youngest generation in Europe.  We need also to make sure that all workers, whatever their jobs, can count on a clear contract with social rights, decent working conditions and full access to social protection; and we want all citizens to have a European social security card and a personal account where they will build their rights to social protection. The skills guarantee must become a new social right for the 21st century.  Finally, we must ensure that women and men can reconcile their working life with family life, using not only childcare services but all the leave schemes we need to legislate the plan. We want poverty to be tackled with more effective minimum—income schemes all over Europe. These are key issues for this pillar, but we want the means to deliver, and the means are labour legislation, changing the way the European Semester works, and addressing the financial means we need to have to implement all these social standards.

name: Marianne Thyssen
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me start by congratulating you on your reappointment as Vice-President of this House.  Almost a year ago, in March 2016, I was announcing to you in this House the launch of a broad discussion on the European social values and rights for the world of work in the 21st century. This was the consultation on establishing the European Pillar of Social Rights, an initiative already announced by President Juncker in the State of the Union address in September 2015. Today, we are here to discuss your own—initiative report, which represents a valuable contribution to the consultation on the European Pillar of Social Rights. I would like to start by congratulating Ms Rodrigues not only for a very ambitious report, but also for her ability to get the support of all political groups in this House for this initiative. During the past year, we have consulted widely at European and national level, engaging European institutions, social partners, civil society, national governments and parliaments and national—level stakeholders. I would like to thank all of you who organised debates here in the European Parliament or in your constituencies on the Pillar of Social Rights. They all contributed to the broader consultation. We have received about 16 500 online replies and nearly 200 position papers. We have been listening to stakeholders’ concerns about their rights, their careers, their life choices and opportunities in the 21st century. We heard a clear call for action. I am convinced more than ever that the debate on social issues should be at the heart of the discussions on what kind of Union our citizens want to have. Next Monday, we will hold a conference at the highest political level, where your rapporteur, Ms Rodrigues, will be one of the main speakers. President Juncker will be there, along with Vice-President Dombrovskis and many ministers and high—level representatives of European social partners and civil society. We also expect the new President of the European Parliament to be there with us. This will be the occasion to reflect on the results of the consultation and to reflect, collectively, where we want to go from here. Following that, the Commission will adopt its final proposal on the Pillar in the spring. I am very happy that your report not only wholeheartedly endorses the Pillar, but that it also appeals for greater ambition. This House has repeatedly called for a better balance between our economic policies and social realities. This is not only an economic or social imperative, but is a political necessity. There is a need to regain the trust of citizens in the European project by reaffirming the commitment to European social values and delivering on this commitment. This is the approach the Commission is following: strengthening the European social model and promoting upward social convergence. Most importantly, your report is a resolute call for action which would make a difference to European citizens. I would like to highlight some of the most important suggestions in your report, which we are considering for the implementation of the Pillar. Your report rightly stresses the need to address new forms of employment and working conditions and calls for horizontal legislation on decent working conditions. We share your view that we have to consider the new forms of employment relationships. But we cannot turn back the clock. We also need to encourage new ways of working. I believe we should not discourage one form or the other, but should ensure that a core of rights is available to everybody. Pivotal to this core of rights, in my view, is that everyone should have a written contract. In this respect, as mentioned in the 2017 Commission Work Programme, we will consult the social partners on revising the Written Statement Directive. Further, I take note of your call to ensure adequate social protection for people in all forms of employment – standard and non—standard employment relationships, and also self-employment. In fact, this message also came out from the consultation on the Pillar: how to ensure that a larger number of people benefit from the coverage of social protection. This is a key question for the future of work and for the sustainability and relevance of the European social model, and that is why the Commission has included in its 2017 Work Programme an initiative on access to social protection. I welcome your call to address the issue of work-life balance. We have already concluded the consultation of social partners, and I am pleased to inform you that we will launch a package of legislative and non-legislative measures to support working families and businesses in spring this year. Our aim is to present a more holistic approach to addressing the challenges of work-life balance – not only for parents, but for other carers as well, and we will propose up-to-date solutions to meet the real needs of today’s families. I do share your concerns about poverty and the fact that we need further efforts to achieve the poverty reduction and social inclusion target of the Europe 2020 Strategy. In this context, your report rightly points out the importance of an adequate income for maintaining human dignity. I agree that decent living wages are important as a means of avoiding in-work poverty. We take note of your recommendation to set up wage floors in the form of a national minimum wage, as that is an issue, but – as you rightly underline – with due respect for the competence and practices of each Member State. As regards reinforcing convergence, the Commission, through its coordinating and facilitating role, helps Member States find ways of achieving upward convergence whilst maintaining competitiveness and a high level of employment and social protection. You also call upon us to put forward a clear roadmap of concrete measures for the full practical implementation of the European Pillar of Social Rights. Here you can count on me. The Pillar must be more than words, so we will chart how we move from political commitment to delivery. This is an agenda which needs to fully engage all stakeholders, in particular Member States, in line with the subsidiarity principle. We are ready to play our part, but the centre of gravity of social and employment policies is, and will remain, with national and local authorities. The primary responsibility for making social rights a reality lies with national governments and social partners. The European Pillar of Social Rights is an opportunity – we could even say an imperative – to address challenges and make the most of opportunities in the changing world of work and society in the 21st century. It is a crucial step towards a shared vision of a more social Europe and a Union founded on fairness. We will need the commitment of all stakeholders – European institutions, national governments and parliaments, social partners and civil society – to achieve these objectives on the ground. We count on Parliament’s support to make sure that the Pillar is not only an aspiration, but will become a reality for all citizens.

name: Maria Arena
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality. - Mr President, Commissioner, I simply wanted to express my thanks to Maria João Rodrigues for the work done on the substance, of course, but also on all the political discussions she was able to hold concerning the pillar of social rights . Commissioner, when we vote on this report, you will have at your disposal a precious tool, fundamental for the objective that Mr Juncker has set for himself, namely the social triple A of the European Union. The pillar of social rights concerns all citizens: children with the guarantee for children, young people with the guarantee for young people and the strengthening of this guarantee, workers, active and job seekers, within the framework of their workers' rights but also social security. Above all, this pillar of social rights has placed equality between men and women at the center of its priorities. The equality that can be obtained through the balance between professional and private life by strengthening parental leave, maternity or paternity leave because, as we know, it is because of these situations that women are today discriminated against in the labor market. Therefore, and you said, these legislative and non-legislative tools must help to fight inequalities. And the first of these inequalities, which is blatant today in Europe, is that between men and women. I am therefore counting on you, Commissioner, and on the Commission as a whole, but also on the Council's political commitment to ensure that this pillar of social rights does not remain a dream or a utopia, but becomes a reality.

name: Tom Vandenkendelaere
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Few quotes from Commission President Juncker were repeated as often as that one sentence from his speech in October 2014. Amid a fragile economic recovery, he then expressed the desire for a social triple A status for Europe, thereby setting the social policy on an equal footing with economic policy and he gave you, Commissioner, an enormous task. You complete this assignment with verve today. While youth unemployment remains a problem, the numbers are falling year after year. But we must not let go of the reins. Every young person who is unemployed at home is one too many. Social indicators are now also included in the semester process. And that's a good thing. You made proposals on how to strengthen the skills and you are working hard on a solution to tackle social dumping, something our construction and transport sectors in Flanders really need. But perhaps even more than the files I just mentioned, it is the social pillar that will shape that famous social triple A status. The expectations are therefore very high. But you also know that the discussions on the role of Europe in social policy are equally heated. By definition, it is a policy where the subsidiarity principle must be fully valid. And let us not regulate at European level what can and must be done at Member State level, but we must also not avoid our responsibility. If Europe can add value, then we must act. In very concrete terms, I am thinking of creating a level playing field for new forms of work versus existing forms of work, a European initiative that can give the Member States the necessary backing to create justice in that area. Commissioner, we look forward to your proposal on that social pillar and I hope that this Parliament own-initiative report can be a source of inspiration for the task ahead of you.

name: Jutta Steinruck
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. -  Mister President! The EU has a chronic deficit when it comes to its social dimension. That is why we need more than just consultations and discussions: we need concrete legislation that strengthens the social dimension of the European Union. It is important for Parliament to adopt very clear lines here today, which the Commission will hopefully take up. For us social democrats, this includes an EU directive for fair and good working conditions. This must apply to all employees, including those who are apparently self-employed today but are actually employed. We want a ban on zero-hour contracts. For us, basic child security, a so-called child guarantee, is very, very important. And a fair Europe needs a social protocol, a Europe-wide minimum income and a silver rule for social investments. Therefore: Please, dear Commission, act now! The social triple-A has been promised for a long time, but little has actually happened so far.

name: Arne Gericke
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr President, Commissioner Thyssen! Let me begin my speech on the report on the social pillar very biblically: Bereshit - in the beginning was the word. Yes, it was the same with the social pillar, which Commission President Juncker first mentioned as a term in his State of the Union speech in 2015. I quote: "I want to develop a European pillar of social rights that can serve as a compass for the euro area." That is how it was written. Unfortunately, empty bodies like the social column invite many of our colleagues in this House, who are very creative in their regulation frenzy, to fill them with suggestions. And that is exactly what happened with the own-initiative report. Not even Juncker's only requirement - a pillar for the euro area - was accepted. No, one cheerfully demands guidelines, specifications, regulations for the EU 28, pretending to have to reinvent social standards for Europe. Dear colleagues, please get our light out from under the bushel! Europe has the highest social standards in the world. We have functioning, positive competition between national social systems and living social partnership. We grow with our diversity and respect subsidiarity. It should stay that way; that is the European social model. And I wish we would further develop this successful model together with the Member States and the social partners, instead of hectic building on a new pillar whose load-bearing capacity I already seriously question. I wish we would implement the existing better instead of constantly throwing new super projects around us, reaching for new power. Europe has a healthy social base, more supportive than any new pillar. I suspect we will one day also say of the social pillar: In the end, it stays with the word.

name: Enrique Calvet Chambon
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr. president. Happy New Year Mrs. Thyssen. It is the first time we see each other, we will see each other much more. I must thank Mrs. Rodrigues and all the fellow co-rapporteurs for the enormous effort they have made with this excellent text and I begin very briefly by asking: Why and what for a social pillar? Let's get to the essentials. A social pillar at this time is essential for three reasons. First, to face the new realities that come from the new forms of work - technology, adaptation to it, the new generations - civil society has to move forward. Second, to combat the inequalities that a serious economic crisis and also the creation of a single currency within the eurozone - a eurozone under construction and growing - have inevitably created, we must take care of people in parallel. And thirdly, to build a more and better Europe around a citizenry that has its model: a model of coherence, of competitiveness within solidarity. That is why we have worked to find fundamental values ​​with Mrs. Rodrigues and with her other colleagues. It is not the labor pillar, it is the social pillar. We talk about the right to decent housing; we are talking, of course, about gender equality and much more. If we stick to these basic texts, the majority of my group will of course vote favorably at this value, because it is a lever, it is a starting point to develop actions — and beware! finance them, as it is very important not to be left in a vacuum—, to favor our civil society, not only in the labor aspect. Obviously we will have difficulties in practical development. But that comes later. Now let's admit the model of European society that we want.

name: Gabriele Zimmer
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, Commissioner! With the title “Pillar of Social Rights” the Commission has made a huge promise, and it is important to keep this promise, otherwise more and more people will be disappointed with the EU and turn to right-wing populism and right-wing extremism. The Commission's first draft, which you mentioned earlier, Commissioner, was disappointing because it actually contained nothing more than what we had previously received as a policy of announcement. We very much hope that, as a result of the public hearing and the participation of initiatives, organizations, people in this public hearing and, of course, the European Parliament, more specific issues will come to the fore with this report. We actually want to encourage you to go in the corresponding direction with your proposal in March. Social rights protect people from exploitation and abuse of power. Protection against dismissal, good collectively agreed wages, poverty-proof minimum income - it's about dignity, it's about personal freedom, and it's about social participation. For this money has to be invested, for that we need concrete measures. And that's why I ask Mr Gericke: If the European social system worked as well as you claim, then I ask myself: Why do 120 million people in the European Union live in poverty? But that doesn't seem to matter to you. We demand that social rights have priority over economic freedoms. The crisis policy pursued by the EPP in recent years has created more poverty. The result is more poverty, more unemployment on the one hand, more wealth, and speculative profits on the other. And we have a political responsibility here to correct things that have gone wrong. That has to be over! We need a real social union. This Parliament has a duty to do more here and I very much support the EU's accession to the Council of Europe's Social Charter.Minimum wages of 60% of the respective median wages in the member states, strengthening of collective bargaining at all levels, a guarantee for children of free access to education, care, housing and good food.Nobody can really contradict that.Thanks again to Ms. Rodrigues for the very ambitious negotiations.She has our support for that.We on the left would like to go further.But that would be a first step.

name: Tamás Meszerics
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, thank you for the floor. Commissioner, rapporteur, ladies and gentlemen, allow me to address you now in the language of my country, Hungarian. I am also doing this because, despite being very few in this Chamber, we should probably have a real debate now on one of the most important reports of the session. Of course, the debates do not always take place here in this room, most of the debates have already taken place during the preparation. First of all, let me thank the rapporteur for her hard work in making this report possible at all, because it was not entirely clear at the first moment whether such a report could be adopted in this House. So one of the biggest advantages of the report is that it exists, there are plenty of concrete proposals in it that we all support individually, but I don’t want to talk about that now. I would like to tell you that the report is about rights, just as the Commission's proposal is about rights. It is not about mere pious principles, which we either enforce or not, but about enforceable rights. If social rights do not exist in Europe, the fragmentation will inevitably continue. Some of my fellow Members prefer to talk about subsidiarity, the only thing is that the principle of subsidiarity is not the lowest level, but the lowest effective level. Take a look at my fellow Members in the nation-states about how effective the protection of social rights is and then decide what the effective level is where this can be addressed. There are also political groups who have opposed the rethinking of any financial instrument during the negotiations, during the preparation of the report, on the grounds of budgetary discipline. Well, now the same groups, and sometimes the same MPs, support ideas without any difficulty where the military lobby puts its hand completely European funds for other purposes.Ladies and gentlemen, we either have budgetary discipline or we use European funds for what they are for, we have to choose from that.If this inconsistency is continued, this inconsistency will disintegrate Europe and not be a stretch of social rights.

name: Laura Agea
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thanks to Mr Rodrigues, Commissioner, in 2015 Juncker spoke of protecting workers through a pillar of social rights, pointing the finger at certain epochal changes in the world of work. Gentlemen, I am sorry to inform you that these are not changes from heaven, it is the reforms encouraged by the Commission that have torn apart the labor market of this continent, such as those imposed on Italians by the Monti government, the Renzi government, and like those imposed on the Greeks by the disturbing alliance between the Commission and the Monetary Fund. Those who work in Europe today no longer have any contractual guarantee and no protection and the responsibility lies with that Commission which today pretends to be taken aback by world changes and points the finger at the global crisis as the cause of all evil. It is not the 2008 crisis that dismantled the old contracts, it was the neoliberal policies aimed at transforming man into a number and the lives of citizens into pure accounting, those neoliberal policies that you now want to continue to impose on us by passing them off as inevitable but these are the same policies that have been in the drawer for a long time, only the right moment was missing to implement extraordinary measures in extraordinary times. We are not very interested in protecting European workers and you can tell us that to our faces, it is written in black and white in the Commission's communications. The ultimate goal of the pillar is not to save people but to enable what is the construction of a deeper economic and monetary union. Human life is subjected to the demands of big finance. It may be a coincidence that, while the Commission launches consultations on the social pillar, the International Fund announces that people are living too long. Yes, because that's what Christine Lagarde said in 2016, then asking governments to apply radical change policies to prevent people's long lives from compromising financial stability.Gentlemen of the Commission, Commissioner, I believe that behind the special effects of your pillar there is actually the intention to follow the disturbing advice of the Monetary Fund.If, on the other hand, your intentions are genuine, then let us clearly understand what concrete actions you will take to truly realize the social pillar, what this social pillar will consist of, beyond documents and words.What will you do, because words do not feed 120 million poor people who are struggling for survival today.There is no need to think about how citizens' lives will lengthen, because today we know that European citizens do not survive.

name: Dominique Martin
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr. President, the claim of this dossier is entirely proportional to its depth and to the artistic vagueness which mix pious wishes for the protection of individuals, equality of opportunity and access to work, economic and above all monetary concepts. You clearly admit certain goals, such as that of creating a European pillar of social rights which can serve as a compass for the convergence of the euro zone, thus clearly stating that this zone has lost the compass. You also admit that harmonization in the field of health and safety at work will require harmonization of social systems, that is to say of their national characteristics, and this to the detriment of subsidiarity and proportionality. All this hardly hides more unofficial goals, such as the capture by states of social budgets to repay their national debts, especially in the euro zone, whose unemployment rate is two points higher than that of non-euro zones. The European Central Bank (ECB) will then be the only one capable of practicing, as it already does for the banks, the "monetary helicopter" intended to supply a safety mattress against poverty. This is not a fiction, it is for tomorrow. If we are to believe the projections of less than ten years, we will see massive losses of secondary jobs by the generalization of digital and robotic processes. It will be the universal income, heir to the European minimum wage, which will thus place all Europeans within the official poverty lines. For all these reasons, we are opposed to this text.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI). - Mr President, the Union is talking about establishing a European pillar of social rights and, at the same time, is systematically promoting the exploitation of workers, sacrificing their future on the altar of serving the financial interests of large multinationals. The same people who talk to us today about social rights are the same people who demand the complete deregulation of the labor market in Greece, they are the same people who, without any explanation, demanded the abolition or complete degradation of collective labor agreements in the private sector. The list of actions of the European institutions is long. In addition to predatory taxation, it also includes the release of collective redundancies, while with the new flexible forms of work, many workers in Greece work, ostensibly, on a part-time basis, but in reality have overtime hours. In combination with the -also imposed- frightening reduction of the basic salary, we have the result, employees work maybe ten hours a day for 250 euros. If you really wanted convergence and even upwards, the first thing you would establish would be a single pan-European base salary. Because you will never do that, I think the purpose is to serve financial interests only.

name: Thomas Mann (PPE).
text: -  Mister President! We have a clear message for workers - both those in employment and those affected by unemployment - that we want a social Europe that will not leave them alone. Working conditions must be fair, welfare systems in the Member States must offer lasting social protection. A European pillar of social rights can identify instruments, but must take into account the independence in the member states: differences in wage developments, differences in minimum wages. We need full transparency, not a secret matter of command. We have to become more visible, more noticeable and more audible. The EPP program - a modern social Europe - is an excellent basis for this in terms of content. I tabled a motion in the Employment Committee that will be voted on today. I proposed to convene an EU social convention - not just online and not just to have a conference, but permanently - to invite those affected: those affected by unemployment, young people, the elderly, the marginalized, social partners are to be involved. We need your experience. The European Parliament will have to play a central role in this, as will the national parliaments - keyword subsidiarity - and civil society. And we need the companies that provide the most training and jobs. And I proposed a special youth social convention. The young people must be able to have their say. We therefore need reform processes for sustainable social systems in the member states and for dynamic labor markets. That is the goal. Then the European Pillar of Social Rights has a chance to be an asset.

name: Marita Ulvskog (S&D).
text: - Mr President!I can agree with very much of what Mr Mann said.There is, after all, a broad consensus on this issue, namely the importance of specifically supporting social development through efforts of the kind that Maria João Rodrigues has produced in her laudable report.I would like to highlight in particular Amendment No 4 on a social protocol.A social protocol would state that fundamental human and trade union rights are not subordinate to the economic freedoms of the internal market.It's central.If the EU cannot secure the basic social rights of citizens, such as equal treatment of workers and the principle of equal pay for equal work, then there is a very high risk that people in more EU countries will turn their backs on the whole European project.We already see it today.Therefore, full support, full support for the proposal that Maria Rodrigues has produced.

name: Czesław Hoc (ECR).
text: - Mr Chairman! Of course, we support active forms of cooperation on social issues: cooperation and social dialogue. We support a Europe without barriers for people with disabilities, tackling child poverty and protecting their rights, strengthening the rights of older people, tackling homelessness, youth employment programs, protection of people excluded from the labor market, Roma rights and integration, etc., but we do not support top-down imposition standards and instruction in isolation from the economic and social realities of individual Member States. There is also no acceptance of violating the principle of subsidiarity and the possibility of deteriorating the competitiveness of individual Member States. In addition, many of these noble goals are, unfortunately, sham activities, there is still child poverty, exclusion, marginalization and unemployment among young people. The report also calls for high-quality employment for women, including in senior positions. So the question - unfortunately rhetorical - how many women have taken up positions in the top three offices of the European Union, ie the head of the European Parliament, the European Commission and the European Council?

name: Morten Løkkegaard (ALDE).
text: - Sir. Chairman! First of all, I would like to say that this is a very sympathetic proposal, it is a very sympathetic thought with the social pillar. There is a need to combine economic and social conditions and have European answers to the challenges that exist in this area. That being said, the competences of the Member States and the Treaties must also be respected, and I assume that the Commission is in favor of this. In this connection, it is no secret that we in the Nordic countries have very well-functioning models in this area, which are about flexibility, and where flexibility is at the center, where it is a question of the social partners voluntarily cooperating to provide the best models. It has been a great success for almost a hundred years. The proposal now available calls for a wide range of legislative interventions, which we are, of course, very concerned about. In this connection, one speaks, among other things. about a statutory European minimum wage, but I am glad that I have seen in the Danish newspapers the Commissioner distancing himself from this. There is a need for a voluntary scheme and, of course, for this to be respected. I would like to ask the Commissioner to confirm that.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, the attack on social rights in Europe has been promoted for decades by the right and social democracy and it stems from your class matrix. Are you concerned about the social deficit in Europe? Defend the regulation of working hours, the workday that does not exceed 8 hours. Equal pay for equal work, the end of any form of precarious work, collective bargaining and the role of workers' organizations, real wage increases and a fair and effective distribution of wealth, universal and solidary public social security, proposals that are not found in this report. This social pillar opens the way for harmonization of work, harmonization of protection and social security systems. It will be another trick that will continue the offensive against workers' rights, to reduce the standards of social and labor rights subjugated to the mechanisms of economic and euro governance, feeding the policies of impoverishment and exploitation. You cannot socially wash an antisocial building and hope that it will result in progress.

name: Terry Reintke (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, there is a poisonous fear going around Europe and the world at the moment: the fear of losing something, of losing jobs, of being deprived of social rights, the fear of ending up in poverty and precariousness, having to work at three jobs, 60 hours a week without breaks, without a pension to prevent poverty, without a security net to fall back on. We can meet this fear with ignorance, by simply denying it exists, but in the end we will all lose when right-wing populists and those wanting to profit from this fear find scapegoats in the weakest members of our societies.  But we can also meet this fear with the strongest asset that this continent holds: solidarity. Yes, to fight inequality we will need to tackle big macroeconomic issues, we will need good regulatory measures and we will need more tax justice. But we will also have to start with the reality of the very ordinary people – of the Romanian child, the worker in Ireland, the unemployed in Greece, the pensioner in the Netherlands. It is precisely through this proposal, the pillar of social rights, that we can meet the fears and the realities of very ordinary people. Mr Juncker said that we need to do big things big in the European Union. I would like to say to Madam Thyssen that this is a big thing and I hope, Madam Thyssen, that you will do this big.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, here we have a classic case of where socialist dreams meet reality. From the hermetically sealed, artificially lit Chamber that we sit in, people decide to make plans and directives and legislation to change the world to achieve socialist utopia: fundamental social rights for children, women and workers all across the EU; a single European social model. Here’s the problem: until then, it’s all so far, so socialist heaven. However, the problem is that we all emerge from the womb free. It’s not for the government or the EU to tell us how free. We’re free to compete; we’re free to have different views; we’re free to do things differently in different countries. Let’s not stand in the way of human nature. Let’s compete, strive and struggle to improve ourselves.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question.- Mr President, honorable Member, what you have just said is something that is completely incomprehensible to me, a clear link between the fact that where there are extensive social rights, there is economic growth, and vice versa.Europe's problem is that social rights are not widely applied, so we cannot grow.Do you refute or confirm this?

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you; I think that’s the first blue card I’ve ever had, so I feel very honoured to have been asked a question! I think there is an absolute link between the European model of social rights and economic growth – it strangles it; it’s the whole reason why the EU lags behind in growth, and why countries outside of it grow quicker, with all these well—intentioned schemes and costly ideas. What you actually do is cripple your economies. A better idea is to live by your means, live how you can afford – and yes, give people good rights and good conditions, but let’s work for them, let’s earn them, and let’s compete for them.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE).
text: - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! There is no doubt that the Member States need to modernize labor markets and social policy. The ever-changing world of work, globalization, digitization, aging society, new business models - these are all phenomena that require quick and effective solutions. According to the announcements of the European Commission, the Social Pillar is to constitute the framework for social policy and employment and is to support reforms at national level. This is a very right direction. Unfortunately, the report adopted by the Employment Committee goes far beyond this in many places. In my opinion, the European Pillar of Social Rights should, first of all, respect the principle of subsidiarity. Due to large differences in the organization of the labor market, Europe is not ready to create uniform solutions for all countries. Secondly, a key element of the pillar should be the enforcement of existing legislation to respect workers' rights. Due to new trends and digitization, we should create a legal framework for new forms of employment without unnecessarily changing the existing good legal solutions. Third, the level of social development is a derivative of economic progress. The pillar should provide a framework and not impose any specific social standards. Better cooperation within the internal market, more efficient movement of workers, goods and services - all these are phenomena that will allow for faster social convergence. I would like to thank the rapporteur of the EPP Group, Tom Vandenkendelaere, for the negotiations conducted, during which he ensured that the applicable subsidiarity principle was respected, especially today very, very important for the Member States, so as not to lead to a deepening of a two-speed Europe.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in a few hours the European Parliament will be called upon to vote on its report on a European pillar of social rights. I am grateful to rapporteur Rodrigues for the forward-looking, ambitious document that she presented, which really sets the course for the revival of Europe. The results of the 2016 public consultation must be read carefully and interpreted as yet another alarm signal about the deterioration of socio-economic conditions in our countries. The European Parliament today must demonstrate that it can do its job. We must demand that the pillar of social rights is not limited to a declaration of good intentions but creates concrete and specific tools, through legislation, through new political mechanisms, with better and more efficient financial instruments. In the list of proposed initiatives, I want to highlight three: obtain a framework directive on decent working conditions in all forms of employment, create a European unemployment insurance system and, finally, demand that the rights of people with disabilities be strengthened and respected. , finding the right space inside the pillar. Let's continue to work on this together.

name: Helga Stevens (ECR).
text: - I am absolutely in favor of a social Europe, but we must dare to ask ourselves how this social Europe can best be achieved. However, this report is going the wrong way. To begin with, it repeatedly violates the principle of subsidiarity. If we do not want to alienate citizens further from the Union, social policy must be implemented as closely as possible to the citizens. The added value of the EU lies mainly in coordinating measures, benchmarking and the exchange of good practices. In this way we can also realize upward convergence. Second, I want to emphasize that social prosperity cannot be built in an economic graveyard. A competitive Europe is an essential condition for a social Europe. Finally, we should not be afraid of flexibility. After all, flexible employment contracts are one of the ways to get people to work or to help them back to work. After all, work is still the best social protection. In addition, and this is also very important to me, it is up to the Member States to provide additional adequate social protection.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, if the social pillar is to be successful and deliver on its stated aims, it has to represent what the citizens of Europe need and want. I hope that through the contributions made by Parliament, social partners and civil society, the social pillar can be aligned so as to guarantee social rights in the manner that citizens deserve and in a manner that will address poverty, income inequality and other serious social injustices. We need to work towards a situation where social policy is not considered a burden to economic growth, but rather that the two are considered to be symbiotic. We must stop the subordination of the social to the economic. It is a chance for the EU to move in the right direction: to prove that it is capable of change. Therefore, I urge the Commission to seize this opportunity and to not let the citizens down. However, if ‘business as usual’ continues, then citizens will suffer and the rise of euroscepticism will continue.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – You just said – and I was totally mystified – that you should subordinate the economic to the social. Surely, if you’ve got an economic mess, you cannot possibly improve people’s social conditions. Surely that is complete common sense, otherwise it’s economic illiteracy. Can you explain to me how, if you’ve got a catastrophic economic situation, you can possibly help people’s social movement or improve their social life. The best way to improve social rights and everything else is to have a booming economy. Everything else, I think, is nonsense. So please enlighten me on how you can reverse gravity. I’d really love to know.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: blue-card answer. – I will happily enlighten you, because we continue to treat the market as though it is some sort of god – ‘we must not interfere with the market’; ‘the market will react’. Well, the market depends on people being able to spend money, and if you don’t have any money, then the markets cannot successfully work. So we need to pay people a decent living wage; we need to ensure that they can rent properties, unlike in my country, Ireland, where they’re being made homeless because they can’t afford the rent and we are having to pay for them to stay in hotels. That’s about subordinating the social to the economic. This week, Oxfam announced that eight billionaires own the same amount of money as 50% of the population of the world. Unless we address that inequality, then I’m afraid your wonderful market is doomed to fail when people don’t have the money to spend in it.

name: Jordi Solé (Verts/ALE).
text: – (The speaker prefaced his remarks with a few words in Catalan.) Mr President, social rights should not be just a pillar of the European Union; they must be their foundation and their priority, because there is no real European project without social justice, and there is no social justice without social investment, without tax justice, without effective redistribution, without accessible and quality public services, without decent working conditions, without the minimum of economic security, without an effective right to housing, without gender equality, and without opportunities for all – especially for the young.  Probably, if the European Union had long had social Europe really on its agenda, we would have better navigated through the crisis that has had such a negative impact on social cohesion in Europe – especially in certain countries, including mine, Catalonia. Let us not make the same mistake again. Let us bring social content finally to the European political project.

name: Anne Sander (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, Europe will be social or it will not be. In fact, we cannot base our living together simply on a single market. Competition is no longer viable without convergence. By supporting this initiative for a social pillar, we are sending a strong message. Parliament wants a Europe which protects precarious employees, which supports young people and seniors, which fights discrimination, which promotes the mobility of apprentices and which allows everyone to find a job. It is also an issue for our small and medium-sized enterprises and our artisans who suffer from social dumping and the lack of coordination between countries. All the measures that we take will have to be careful not to complicate recruitment and not to trample on subsidiarity. On new digital jobs, I believe there is an urgent need to clarify the applicable rules to promote a digital economy that is fair and equitable. But to create a new directive when we still have not defined these new jobs is, in my opinion, premature. Dear colleagues, Social Europe is a priority and, for my part, I will vote for this report.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D).
text: - Europe today lacks, as never before, a strong social base to maintain confidence in the European Union. People want to live better, have a stable job, income, feel economic and financial security, secure the future of their children. The European Union and the Member States must therefore work together to combat growing poverty, especially child poverty. I call on the Commissioner: there is an urgent need to set up a Child Guarantee, which will provide specific, financially sound measures to help children in need throughout the European Union. We must also create a family-friendly environment for people to reconcile work and private life. However, this requires the Commission to bring forward legislation on maternity and paternity leave, to improve the conditions for parental leave and to adopt the Nurses Directive at EU level. Commissioner, I thank you wholeheartedly for reaffirming today that you will present the whole package on reconciling work and private life in the spring, and we are ready to work together.

name: Zbigniew Kuźmiuk (ECR).
text: - Mr Chairman! In taking the floor in this debate, I would like to point out that the actions of the European Commission that it will take on the social affairs pillar should respect the principle of subsidiarity. I would like to point out that in my country, Poland, the pro-natalist program "Family 500+" has been implemented for nearly a year, supporting with the amount of nearly EUR 120 per month for a child of families raising two or more children, as well as less affluent families with one child. The program concerns nearly 4 million children, i.e. about half of all children up to the age of 18, and costs PLN 23 billion annually, i.e. nearly 1.5% of Polish GDP, and is a great investment for the young generation. On this occasion, I would like to ask the Commission that programs of this kind implemented by individual Member States may be supported in the future by the European Social Fund. After all, demographic problems are experienced by the vast majority of EU countries.

name: Κωνσταντίνα Κούνεβα (
text: GUE / NGL). - Mr President, Europe is proud of its social model, but if we look at the unemployed in Greece or the workers in Britain and Germany with the "zero" contracts, ie the slaves of the 21st century, we realize that our famous model is being destroyed. Because the European Union has strict rules for budgets and markets, it provides for penalties and fines, but it has no similar rules for labor and social rights except words and wishes. The social pillar, which provides for free collective bargaining for wages and other conditions of cooperation, must oblige each country, the Commission and the European Bank to support this position. Therefore, not to impose the abolition of collective agreements and to hide behind the IMF as they try to do in Greece.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE).
text: - Madam President, dear colleague Maria João Rodrigues, there are many points of convergence between the PPE and the socialists regarding the European project. This has been the case throughout the history of this institution. We agree that economic policies must have a positive social effect, that there must be adequate funding for European policies and programs. We agree that economic convergence has not been accompanied by the desired social convergence. The central issue lies in the mechanisms that must be activated so that there is also harmonization at the social level, fulfilling the European project. But there are points that separate us, Madam. In order to be able to contribute to the development of Europe, we cannot fail to take into account the functioning of it, to consider what are the competences of the Commission and what are the competences of the Member States, because if we do not do this we will be making vain promises to our fellow citizens. Do not count on me for demagogic proposals, so arbitrary that they become empty, nor that they jeopardize the sovereignty of the Member States or disrespect the social partners. While you have been, in the last few hours, holding press conferences accusing the PPE of perverting your report, we were negotiating so that we can approve a European social pillar in a little while. Without the EPP amendments, this would not have been possible. We did it, because what moves us is not party politics, what moves us is the defense of the interests of European citizens.

name: Георги Пирински (S&D).
text: - Today, this Parliament has a truly historic chance to chart the direction for a truly new course for Europe. The Rodriguez report on the European Pillar of Social Rights defines the basic characteristics of a new social Europe as the only chance for the European Union to regain the trust of its citizens and to restore its status as offering the highest quality of life. We are talking about the adoption of a framework directive on decent work for all forms of employment, including those arising from digitalisation; expanding social security systems to cover all people employed in all forms of work, including the self-employed; guarantees of decent wages and coordinated increases in national minimum wage levels to 60% of weighted average national wage levels. It is high time to respond to the will of the people. Here is the declaration of the Bulgarian trade unionists: "If these main paragraphs are dropped from the report, the planned improvements in working and living conditions in Europe will be jeopardized and the frantic desire to keep the exploitation contract for zero hours of employment will remain." to allow something like this to happen.

name: Javi López (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner. We are facing the greatest challenge that the European Union is going to have in the coming years in this second part of the mandate. A social pillar, a pillar of social rights that recovers the European soul; to reconnect with millions of citizens who have disconnected from the European institutions in recent years; that it tries to fix a good part of the institutional problems of the euro currency and, at the same time, that it recover the will for convergence and redistribution that the European Union should have. Given this, concrete measures such as a table of minimum wages, the improvement of collective bargaining, the child guarantee, the will to have an unemployment mechanism, a European unemployment benefit, that allow having a goal. A social pillar that goes beyond a letter of good will. We cannot repeat the mistakes that we have made with Europe 2020 or the Lisbon Strategy, which have remained a dead letter, taking into account that today we have 120 million poor people or people at risk of social exclusion in Europe.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - I agree that we guarantee fundamental rights at European Union level, including social rights, and help the Member States to develop good social policies, to reduce unemployment. The Commissioner has rightly said here that employment and social security policy remains fully in the hands of the Member States, and we will respect that. The report repeatedly mentions the European model of the welfare state. I must point out that there is no such thing. We have 28 social policies, which are based on 3 models of the welfare state according to their historical and political development. The social and wage convergence that we want across European countries cannot be achieved by central regulations and new directives, but only by economic growth, political stability and greater efficiency. If we are to build a pillar of social rights, we must build it on solid foundations and the acceptance of all countries. Did we learn from Brexit?

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the protracted crisis in the euro area has dealt a severe blow to the social dimension of European integration. Many Member States have been forced to implement stringent fiscal consolidation measures which have resulted in severe social hardship. Without a common European framework, Member States are bound to be trapped in destructive competition based on a race to the bottom of social standards. A European pillar of social rights can only be credible if accompanied by adequate resources at national and European level capable of guaranteeing the achievement of the established objectives. If necessary, the multiannual financial framework 2014-2020 should be reviewed, the Youth Employment Initiative further strengthened and the full use of the EDF and the European Fund for Aid to the Most Deprived should be ensured. These financial instruments must also be strengthened with reference to education and training, professional retraining, the fight against poverty and unforeseen challenges until a few years ago, such as the integration of refugees into the labor market.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). - Mr President, the European Commission is talking about the social dimension of the European Union and the social 'triple A', and even now it continues to support the policy of austerity that has filled Europe with armies of the unemployed and 120 million poor. A policy that sent the new generation into mass unemployment and underemployment. The European Union, with the Stability Pact and the violent fiscal adjustment, has dismantled the welfare state and the pension system. At the same time, in countries with memoranda, such as Greece, Ireland, Cyprus, Portugal and Spain, salaries and pensions were cut. In fact, in Greece, the troika does not even recognize the right to enter into collective agreements. So if you want, gentlemen of the European Commission, social Europe, leave the big words and the famous conferences and abandon austerity and memoranda, abolish the Stability Pact, adopt policies for the fair distribution of the wealth produced, abandon the policy of flexible working relations , support the pan-European single wage.

name: António Marinho e Pinto (ALDE).
text: - The so-called “European Pillar of Social Rights”, as presented here by the rapporteur Maria João Rodrigues, must be seen as the cornerstone of European cohesion.Among these rights, of course, the right to a European minimum wage stands out, that is, to a limit below which it is not allowed to pay work.Social rights are today one of the fundamental dimensions of human rights and these, taken as a whole, can only be realized historically if people's basic needs are satisfied.For this reason, the fight against poverty today assumes, in this context, a strategic significance not only for its effects on economic growth, but above all as a relevant factor of social peace.Poverty always ends up generating violence.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, social rights are the great absent from the European construction and for this reason we are surprised by the Commission's proposal to create a social pillar of rights. With surprise, but also with some perplexity, since the economic policies promoted by the European Union within the framework of the euro are summarized in the progressive dismantling of the institutions that protect the working majority. It would not be the first time, unfortunately, that the European Commission promises us something to offer us the opposite. That is why it is important to listen to Parliament, which in this report details many of the initiatives necessary so that the pillar of social rights is not just another smokescreen. Compliance with the European Social Charter, a framework directive on decent work, a system of minimum incomes above the poverty line, the reinforcement of collective bargaining: all are concrete and necessary initiatives that the Commission must take into account.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (
text: NI). - Mr President, the more the charitable slogans of the EU institutions increase under popular outrage, the worse the labor jungle becomes. The European pillar of social rights is an insidious effort, through always cheap slogans, in order to finally leave arrangements for the deterioration of the situation of workers. It squeezes labor social rights down, promoting a 'fair share' between the poor and the impoverished, eliminating any burden on employers. Full-time work is dangerously transformed into a decent, supposedly, job and a sufficient mere subsistence income. It promotes active aging, that is, partial retirement with part-time work, extortionately, after pensions were crumpled. It prepares raising the age limits based on life expectancy, promotes the determination by the state of the minimum and minimum wage, the tombstone "collective labor contracts" based on competitiveness, profits, for which salaries, allowances, rights are permanently sacrificed. It talks about salaries per region, ie special economic zones and scams. Employees to worry about! To organize, to counterattack!

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Mr President, while I commend the report for pointing out the vast number of social challenges EU countries are faced with, I find that it misjudged the causes of problems and consequently insists on the wrong solution. The issue is not that the EU is not social enough. I would point out that the EU accounts for approximately 7% of the world’s population but around 40% of global public social expenditure.  Existing social challenges are not so much a result of missing social policy but mainly of insufficient reforms, including to the labour market, and the lack of economic growth and job creation. A more social Europe should not be one that throws money at every problem it identifies, or one that stifles competitiveness – a precondition for job creation and sustainable social protection. Rather, in full respect for subsidiarity, it should be one that promotes sound economic policies and encourages national reforms in areas such as education and active labour market policies.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D).
text: - Mr President, the first of the rights that the European Union must ensure for its citizens is obviously the right to work. But that is not enough, this work must be decent work that allows everyone to live their life, to make their personal choices and to participate in collective life. Intended to enlighten the Commission on what the European pillar of social rights should be, the report by Maria João Rodrigues is a comprehensive response to the promises made here by Mr Jean-Claude Juncker on the social triple A. This right to work must include other protective rights for employees, men and women, who must not be faced with the uncertainty of the next day. Indeed, how to build your life with a zero hour employment contract? How to build your life worrying about not having a retirement pension? How to build your life in the fear of not being treated in case of illness? How, today, to build his life without access to public services and digital? The Union must answer these questions and, of course, secure the necessary funding for them. Without it, we would remain in the domain of the incantation.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE).
text: - Mr Chairman! The European Pillar of Social Rights was announced in September 2015. Last year, a very extensive consultation took place and I am pleased that the European Parliament has taken the initiative to contribute to this discussion. I believe - as do many of my colleagues here in the room - that in the face of dynamically changing employment conditions and global economic trends, Member States should work together on employment and social issues to ensure that Union citizens have adequate labor and social security standards. It should be noted, however, that under the Treaties, the Member States have exclusive competence over social security systems and the role of the Union is to act to strengthen this cooperation. However, we must bear in mind that the huge diversity of local practices and the still incomplete cohesion between individual labor markets mean that I consider the proposals, for example, a common minimum income or a single European unemployment insurance, to be a path in the wrong direction.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D).
text: – Domnule vice-președinte, vă felicit pentru realegerea în această funcție importantă. The European Pillar of Social Rights is making substantial achievements for Europe and the citizens we represent, and I would like to congratulate our rapporteur Rodriguez for her important work. This pillar goes beyond political interest, and it reminds us that the European Union is here to bring improvements in living and working conditions in Europe. Nevertheless, some people in this House still act to maintain precarious, unregulated forms of work, and to keep millions of Europeans uncertain about basic rights such as maternity leave or protection of health and safety at the workplace. Young people – my generation – cannot wait anymore for those people to wake up and realise that without action we condemn our future generations to poverty. We need to build our legislation on decent living conditions; we need to stop the exploitation of zero—hour contracts; we need decent living wages, and we need to properly finance European instruments capable of delivering results in terms of jobs, skills and social protection. So, dear colleagues, if you have in mind to support some of the amendments opposing that, please forget about it.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Mr President, the European Union is going through a crisis of confidence and a social crisis. The main antidote to the crisis is the European pillar of social rights and we must act. I would like to congratulate her and thank our rapporteur, Mrs Rodriguez, for her excellent report, the proposed measures and the arguments put forward. The European pillar of social rights can fundamentally change the lives of our citizens, the lives of children, young people, the elderly, people with disabilities, workers. I supported all the amendments proposed by Mrs Rodriguez because I believe in them. I believe in the urgent need to give a signal to people that we care about their lives. The promotion of economic activities must all take into account a primary purpose, that of serving the people. There is a need to increase the accountability of businesses, local and central national authorities on social rights. By solving social problems, we achieve a threefold effect: attachment to the workplace, increased productivity and attachment to the European Union. I urge all colleagues to vote on the report and, once again, I congratulate our colleague.

name: Marju Lauristin (S&D).
text: – Mr President, there is a saying that it is better do something good late than never. I think that if we had had the European Pillar of Social Rights at the beginning of the enlargement process, we would not now have such big differences between the new Member States and the old ones. It is very good that, before making the very important changes which come with the digital revolution, we are now discussing what we have to do with regard to social rights and defining social protection for decent working people in this new situation. We very much hope that we will do this in time and that, before these jobs disappear and new jobs arrive, we will have an understanding of the new social policy and standards and the common social pillar. Then we will an upward convergence rather than a downward one, which is what we have seen up to now.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, this report is a key milestone, and we must indeed refocus the delivery of the EU 2020 objectives of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, paying much more attention to social education and employment targets, as well as properly recognising the contribution of culture in reaching the so-called Social Triple A for the development and wellbeing of individuals and societies. The European Commission has already acknowledged that austerity has increased inequalities, social injustice and poverty in Europe. Children are among the most impacted and remain the group at the highest risk of poverty and social exclusion. If this situation is not properly addressed through decisive political action, we risk excluding a great part of the next generation. So, as a member of the Intergroup on Children’s Rights, I am proud that the report we are about to adopt includes a call for the creation of a child guarantee, in line with the ‘Investing in Children’ recommendations, that will ensure that every child in Europe at risk of poverty – including refugees – has access to free healthcare, free education, free childcare, decent housing and adequate nutrition.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Domnule președinte, vă felicit pentru cel mai mare număr de voturi obținut de un vicepreședinte al Parlamentului European. I strongly believe that we have to make strong efforts in order to adapt our social security systems to the living and working conditions Europeans will have in the 21st Century, ensuring that everyone has the necessary education and skills and gets decent living wages, maternity leave, sick leave, pensions and child care. The single market needs rules on decent working conditions in all forms of employment, so that all working people have basic rights regardless of the type of their contract. Decent national wage floors must be ensured in all European Union countries, secondary education should be compulsory and the skills guarantee should ensure that everyone has the skills needed in tomorrow’s economy. A child guarantee should ensure that every child at risk of poverty has free healthcare, child care, education, adequate nutrition and decent housing.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: - Mr President, honorable Members, it has been a long time, almost three decades, before we have realized on this continent that the money spent on education is not just an expense, it is certainly an investment. Investing, obviously investing in people. Well, we have the same millions of other social implications, as all the pennies, cents, euros we spend on strengthening the pillar of European social rights are all items that increase Europe's gross domestic product, European GDP, although apparently sometimes this expenditure you pull the page, but you pull the spending page because everyone can spend as much for certain purposes as they want. So I would encourage the rapporteur, and I would all encourage all of us, to see the enforcement of social rights as a kind of European investment, a European investment. Finally, I would like to confirm what the rapporteur said in his opening statement: this is not a pillar of the euro area, it is a pillar of the whole of the European Union, and even a pillar of all people working in Europe.

name: Liisa Jaakonsaari (S&D).
text: - (FI) Mr President, Europe's deepest economic crisis has changed Europe mentally, politically and economically.In fact, we are still living mentally in that time of economic crisis, and many Member States are still pursuing an over-emphasized, exaggerated austerity policy.Now is really the last time to change this policy, and the Rodrigues report serves it very well.I hope that this will inspire the Member States and the European Union to take into account the major changes that are currently still posing challenges for Europe in the wake of the long tail of the economic crisis.Mr Lauristin mentioned one of them: digitalisation challenges Europe and the labor market, aging challenges Europe and the labor market, and all of these challenge the European social model.

name: Marianne Thyssen
text: Member of the Commission. - I would firstly like to thank Parliament for this debate and of course I would like to thank Parliament, the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs first of all for the rich and ambitious report that I hope, but it also looks like that it would receive the broad support of this house if it was voted on in plenary. Dear Members of Parliament, honorable rapporteur, I see your contribution as a source of inspiration, but also as support in achieving our shared ambitions. The European Union is a place where by no means everything runs and turned out perfectly, but where we must say that the social dimension has taken shape more than in other places in the world. More than anywhere else in the world, we have, through us, made a work together so that there is a good combination of economic growth and social progress, the hallmarks of the social market economy, one of the objectives of the European Treaty. More than elsewhere in the world, wealth has been redistributed, although this does not prevent inequality from increasing in Europe as well. But the world is changing and it is changing rapidly. We are still dealing with the aftermath of the crisis and we have seen that it has also meant that instead of more convergence, we have gained more divergence between Member States. But the world is also changing mainly due to globalization and digitization, which have a profound impact on our economy and our way of living and living together. Those changes worry people. People are indeed concerned about their freedom and security, about democracy, but also about their economic and social future and that future is what the pillars are all about. We need a new frame of reference, a new frame of reference against which we can test employment and social policy, new starting points. We have to look at how we can ensure that in new circumstances, in times of globalization, in times of technological change, how we can also ensure that the principles of our social market economy take shape in Europe during that period. This means that we have a competitive economy, where quality jobs are created, but where work is also done on sustainable and adequate social protection, and that throughout the life course of people. We therefore need a reference work and indeed we also need concrete action. Words and frames of reference alone are not enough. We have to work on that matter. And we will start on that very soon and we will use the tools for that, the instruments that we have available. Legislative? yes, where we have powers and where appropriate. But also benchmarking, coordination and also the use of our funds, of our financial resources. More than ever, the debate on social issues is part of the debate about what Europe we want, how we see the future of our European Union. That is why, as the rapporteur has rightly said here in the introduction to her report, this debate is of fundamental importance. It is therefore good that we kept it here. It was more than ever time and I want to thank you very much for that. We still have a lot of work to do and I hope that when it comes to the concrete, we can work together very well. Thank you.

name: President. –
text: Before I give you the floor, Ms Rodrigues, Mr Løkkegaard would like to add something. Twenty seconds, you mentioned?

name: Morten Løkkegaard (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, thank you for that. I don’t know whether the interpreter got my question to you, Commissioner, but I asked if you could confirm that you actually said to the Danish press that this minimum wage discussion is a matter of subsidiarity and that we will find national solutions to this. Could you confirm that?

name: Marianne Thyssen
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, it is true that wages as such are not part of the competences at European level. It is said explicitly in the Treaty that wages belong to the competence of Member States, and I think that is right because it also respects the autonomy of the social partners who, in most Member States, have a say or have to decide on this, but it does not necessarily prevent us from setting benchmarks. If we want to go to convergence between Member States, that could be good and it can be one of our objectives – that we look all together at what is a decent minimum wage, and what elements we need to decide upon that. We encourage Member States to set a minimum wage, but in the end the decision belongs to the Member States, and it is a principle that we have to respect. We want to respect the distribution of competences as foreseen in the Treaty.

name: President. –
text: The Commissioner was not obliged to respond to this question, but I am very glad that she did, because we have now clarified this matter.

name: Maria João Rodrigues
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, today’s debate was very important  because it was made clear for everybody that, with this report, Parliament sees what is at stake, which is making sure that there will be a turning point in the direction in which the European project is going. Without a stronger social dimension, there is no future for the European Union. This came out of this debate very clearly. I believe that with this report we can lay down the conditions for a new stage of European social policy because what is at stake is no longer only making a level playing field for the single market to operate. We do need this, but it is not enough. What is at stake is also being able to cope with common challenges, notably the upcoming digital revolution which will profoundly change the way in which the markets operate. What is at stake is to organise a full process of upward economic and social convergence in the European Union and inside the eurozone. In order to do this we need to combine powerful means: labour and social law, changing the direction of economic governance, and providing the necessary financial means. Regarding the so—called European Semester, we need to have stronger social targets along with economic targets, focusing on the problems of unemployment, social inequalities and poverty to make sure that economic policy takes into account the social impact. We need to have a new kind of interaction between economic and social policy. Secondly, we need to have the appropriate means, starting with the means for social investment in education, training, tackling poverty and providing good social services. This should also be translated into the Community budget, the European Fund for Strategic Investment, as well as a proper fiscal capacity in the eurozone. These ideas are included in our report and, through these, we also want to establish positive cooperation between our colleagues in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and those in the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. This is the kind of cooperation we need to develop in order to implement such a pillar.  I would like to thank all the shadows once again. Our citizens are making a clear call for a strong social union. Now we just need to deliver.  (Applause)

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place today at 12 noon.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. - The social dimension is largely absent from EU policies. The single market was built without providing for its integration and this has created and continues to create internal dumping and risks for workers. The so-called "European social model" in vogue at the end of the last century must be updated, but, above all, the social dimension must become an integral part of common policies. The report addresses important elements such as income redistribution, collective social security schemes, social assistance programs, public services, services of general interest, social investments and the fight against tax evasion. However, these instances are placed in a context that provides for greater coordination at the level of European governance which, as structured today, actively contributes to incentivizing inequalities and impoverishment of the majority of European citizens, in particular through the imposition of a block on public spending. of the individual Member States.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE / NGL), in writing. - The European Parliament's Committee on Employment's report on a European social rights pillar contains a number of well-founded findings, such as that the social dimension of European integration has been hit hard by the eurozone crisis, as many countries have been forced to implement tough internal devaluation measures. the lack of common stabilization mechanisms in the context of incomplete monetary union. It is also undeniable that, as the report states, with this crisis the European Union has begun to be seen by many citizens as a mechanism that creates divergence, inequality and social injustice. The report also calls on the European Commission to work with the social partners to put forward a proposal for a framework directive to promote decent work, in order to ensure, inter alia, the right to collective bargaining and collective action. of the strike.
