The problem, however, is that the European Commission not only fails to bring a similar draft directive to Parliament, but with its policy degrades collective bargaining when it acts as a member of the "troika" under the Greek program and imposes a weakening of the collective agreements in Greece. So we need works, not words, and we need them immediately.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: written.- I am convinced that economic integration within the EU must be accompanied by social policy.The European market economy is a social market economy.That is why there must also be a social policy at European level that shapes market processes in the interests of the citizens.The European Pillar of Social Rights should therefore play a supporting, complementary and coordinating role.In doing so, however, it must be taken into account that in the social policy area the competences do not lie with the EU, but with the Member States, and that the principle of subsidiarity applies here: the organization of dismissal protection, retirement age or parental leave is a matter for the Member States.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: signed up. - EU Member States are currently facing social and employment challenges, but also a continuous evolution of this market, with 'atypical' or 'non-standard' forms of employment: temporary work or part-time, seasonal work or that mediated by digital platforms. In addition, we are witnessing a diversification of the workforce, which can bring benefits and can generate other professional opportunities, but can also generate inconveniences - prolonged economic insecurity, poor working conditions, lower and less secure incomes, lack of social security and health, lack of career prospects and difficulties in reconciling work and family life. I therefore believe that adequate and more substantial strategic investments are needed to achieve the EU's social and employment goals, as well as more substantial support for cohesion in disadvantaged regions, in order to make them more competitive and prevent accentuating the demographic decline, with a focus on reducing child poverty, and taking concrete measures to ensure free access to health care, education, decent housing and adequate nutrition.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: written. - The European Social Pillar was announced by President Juncker before the European Parliament on 9 September 2015. The European Pillar of Social Rights establishes a series of essential principles to support just and functioning labor markets and social protection systems correctly for the euro area. The areas of action of the Pillar are grouped into three main branches; equal opportunities and access to the labor market, fair working conditions and adequate social protection. The report highlights that people who are in vulnerable situations or who are more frequent victims of discrimination, such as women, ethnic minorities, the long-term unemployed, senior citizens and people with disabilities may need measures complementary activities aimed at promoting their participation in the labor market and guaranteeing decent living standards throughout their lives; In this regard, it should also be noted that the report insists that the rights of persons with disabilities must be integrated throughout the social pillar with a human rights-based approach that is in line with the obligations of the Union and its Member States in under the CRPD

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing. - Social systems in most European countries are still an example to the rest of the world in terms of their functioning and results. Nevertheless, experience and the consequences of the economic and debt crisis have weakened confidence in their functioning. The European Pillar of Social Rights aims to reform social systems and better adapt them to the conditions of the 21st century. Social systems must once again have the trust of the people. They must provide effective guarantees and deal with shocks, especially in difficult times of economic crisis. Conditions and needs in the social systems of European countries vary. However, the common goal is the prosperity of citizens. We are certainly united in this in Europe. To achieve this, effective cooperation is important, not blinded calls to break up the European Union and incite mutual hostility. The aim must be to create sustainable jobs, but also to ensure decent and fair working conditions. Also reducing unbearable social disparities while supporting social investment. Better regulation of international capital with a focus on tax systems is also a condition. There is a need to prevent more money spilling from European countries with proper tax systems into any tax havens.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. - Every effort must be made to ensure that the European Union reacts quickly and visibly to the growing frustrations and concerns of a large part of the citizens. Ordinary answers are no longer possible: uncertain life prospects, unemployment, growing inequalities require us to take concrete and urgent action on the side of social Europe. New tools are needed, new concrete measures to support those in greatest difficulty and to relaunch the entire pillar of social rights in innovative ways. The European Commission has launched a consultation and the social partners have reacted with some proposals of great interest. Parliament's response is now one of great ambition, through the listing of very precise priorities on how to structure the European social model for the future. I would particularly like to recall the passages in the Rodrigues report which reiterate the importance of collective bargaining as a primary fundamental right of the EU. From this principle emanates the conviction, expressed several times by this House, of how it can be both right and useful for growth to involve employees in the management of companies, through the introduction, as much as possible, of information measures. , consultation and participation, especially in order to achieve new and better models of work organization and to anticipate economic changes.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: in writing. - The European Pillar of Social Rights is part of the work undertaken by the European Commission towards a deeper and fairer Economic and Monetary Union (EMU). It also sets the course for action towards better convergence in the euro area. The EU should react without delay to the growing frustration of many over an uncertain future, unemployment and a lack of prospects, especially for young people. It is also necessary to strengthen the foundations of European integration and increase the sense of belonging to a community among the inhabitants. The European Pillar of Social Rights should contribute to the proper application of international labor standards and the modernization of the social acquis. Moreover, the standards to be enshrined in the European Pillar of Social Rights should apply to all countries participating in the Single Market, and the legislation and governance mechanisms needed to achieve them should apply to all EU Member States. Certain restrictions resulting from participation in the euro area require the setting of additional social goals and standards and consideration of financial support at the euro area level, open on a voluntary basis to non-euro area Member States.

name: Jaromír Kohlíček (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Thousands of parties have already described the European Pillar of Social Rights in various contexts within the EU. Especially in the last decade, there is such a large amount of materials that it is difficult to just monitor them, let alone ensure their fulfillment. The current EP report on this subject therefore contains 71 references to various conventions, charters and studies. Perhaps the oldest of these, the Schuman Declaration of May 9, 1950, already called for "equalization and improvement of the living conditions of workers." Unfortunately, the aforementioned 1950 Declaration, as well as many others that followed, has not been fulfilled, and there seems to be no chance of being fulfilled in the system in the near future. The world's leading economists point to the accelerated opening of the scissors among an ever-narrowing group of the richest owners and a rapidly expanding majority of those living on the brink of social need. The whole report therefore shows a huge inequality between the creation of good conditions for the free movement of capital and social conditions in individual EU countries. Despite the declared efforts, their huge differences are not only not being reduced, but are increasing in a number of areas. The solution can obviously be only a systemic change, which, however, is so far only sought by the parties of the authentic left.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: in writing. - The report on social rights before the European Parliament already threatens the sovereignty of the Member States and the principle of subsidiarity itself. Nevertheless, the document contains a number of elements that we support and have already been implemented in Hungary. Without claiming a complete list, the most important results of the recent period include e.g. 90 percent of young children eat for free three times a day, and disadvantaged children also get food for free during school breaks. Significant progress has also been made in raising the minimum wage over the past 25 years. With regard to the institutional placement and long-term care provided in the report, large people with disabilities placed in rural institutions (3,500-4,000 people) will also be relocated to smaller housing units. The reduction of overheads so far and new home-building solutions and initiatives are also important, and from March this year, numerous fees and charges related to public administration will be abolished. VAT has been reduced for milk, eggs and poultry, among others, for the benefit of the poorest consumers. Through the Digital Welfare Program, a discounted internet package will also be available. The workplace action plan helps to employ an average of 900,000 workers a year, so the employment levels of women and young people have also increased significantly. In the field of tax evasion and avoidance, VAT revenues increased by HUF 1,000 billion, or almost a third, compared to 2011, following the success of online cash registers.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: In written form. - Changing social realities in Europe can lead to imbalances that are detrimental to the competitiveness of the European economy and long-term growth potential. It is therefore important that we seek answers to these challenges on the basis of common principles that ensure that economic growth leads to high levels of employment and social protection, demonstrating the benefits of European integration for all citizens. Social policy is not limited to the provision of social benefits and pensions through the redistribution of budgetary resources, but must be seen above all as an investment that will bring long-term benefits by making European citizens more independent and empowered. I believe that the European Pillar of Social Rights must give priority to the issue of access to health services and health inequalities, which have significant consequences for the economy and society as a whole. In this regard, I believe that it is important for the new pillar to apply to all Member States, because the countries with the biggest problems in providing universal health coverage are outside the euro area.

name: Verónica Lope Fontagné (PPE)
text: written. - European citizens have long been asking Europe to focus on social issues, and I therefore want to express my satisfaction with this report, as it will help to better balance economic policies and social needs, support labor markets and systems of fairer protection and will strengthen the European social model, helping to achieve upward economic, social and territorial convergence. From the EU we have to face important current and future challenges such as the digitization of the economy and the consequent appearance of new jobs and work modalities, demographic challenges or the scourge of poverty, which unfortunately is still very present in our society . The reduction of poverty and social exclusion should be one of the pillars of the social pillar since current growth can only be sustainable if it includes all citizens. To achieve this we have to work together in the short term, through policies that make it possible to alleviate existing poverty and favor entry into the labor market, and in the long term, through policies capable of breaking the cycle of poverty, mainly focused on education and education. reduction of school dropouts.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D)
text: in writing. - Article 2 of the so-called Lisbon Treaty, amending the Treaty on European Union and the Treaty establishing the European Community (2007 / C 306/01), stipulates the fight against social exclusion, the promotion of social justice, cohesion and solidarity as one of the European Union's main tasks. I would like to contrast these goals with the shocking results of the recent report by the international charity Oxfam, which focuses on the unequal distribution of wealth around the world, including the European Union. Yes, even on the territory of our continent, there is a very dangerous spread of scissors among the rich and poor sections of the population, which the right-wing governments are successfully helping. They thus keep Europe in an imbalance that hinders the improvement of working and living conditions for all and thus contributes to the unhealthy escalation of the political situation. Our Group of Socialists and Democrats is fighting for upward social convergence, for raising social standards that are truly in line with the 21st century. We are fighting for a better European economic governance, strengthening the European Social Fund, ensuring a minimum income for Europeans, protecting against the negative effects of globalization resulting in collective redundancies, protecting all children at risk of poverty and education. I therefore support a strong European pillar of social rights that fits into the concept of social Europe. We do not need a complicated Europe, the existence of which is based on secret right-wing agreements and services to multinational companies. We need a transparent European Union that focuses primarily on the needs of its citizens.

name: Soraya Post (S&D)
text: in writing. – More than 122.3 million people live at risk of poverty and social exclusion in the EU, such as the Roma, its largest minority, most of whom live in extreme poverty, face widespread and severe social exclusion, and often experience barriers in accessing major EU programmes. Therefore, the main goal of the Social Pillar should be to lift these people out of this situation and break the cycle of poverty and social exclusion, thereby also reaching SDGs. This, however, is only possible if the planned Social Pillar is not limited to be developed in the eurozone. Non-euro countries struggle with similar social and employment-related challenges, and thus leaving them out might result in an even greater social divergence. For a truly social Europe, in which we leave no one behind, the principle of equal treatment and non-discrimination and that of gender equality have to be mainstreamed throughout the planned Social Pillar. There should be special measures taken to reach out to socially—disadvantaged people by planned structural reforms and social investments, in order to enable and empower them, and there should be a clear and viable implementation roadmap with strong monitoring and evaluation with the involvement of civil society organisations.

name: Christine Revault D’Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: in writing. - The report on the European Pillar of Social Rights is a landmark report in the construction of a social Europe at the service of European citizens. This report is the European Parliament's response to the commitments that President Juncker has still not kept in favor of a Europe of social triple A. A strong and ambitious response that comes in several concrete proposals: a framework directive on decent work, a directive for health at work or the integration of a social protocol into the treaties to guarantee fundamental social rights. This report also proposes far-reaching reforms in order to put in place a decent minimum income throughout Europe. The Commission will have to take all these proposals into account if it is to meet its commitments. Finally, I call on you not to vote on the amendments which aim to lower the level of ambition of the report and to distort its proposals. It is the weakness of the social dimension of the internal market that is fueling the rejection of the European project today. Social Europe is the alternative to the projects of the populists who advocate inward looking. We must send a clear and unambiguous message to European citizens.

name: Bart Staes (Verts/ALE)
text: written. - Anyone who says high-quality job creation automatically thinks of a green and social economy. If we want to strengthen the social pillar in Europe, we need to protect social rights: equal rights, for equal work, or whether employees are temporarily or permanently employed. We have known that for a long time, and we have been saying it for a long time. This report is a creditable contribution to go beyond fine words and principles. Job creation and green economy go hand in hand: new jobs in the energy sector, for house insulation, it is often SMEs that are employers. In addition to social protection, they also want flexibility. This is understandable, but not without the necessary social protection, job security and a good balance between work and leisure. The approach through cooperative societies also proves its usefulness as a sustainable organizational model for SMEs. Co-ownership, employee participation are ingredients for a social and solidarity-based economy that makes social protection of employees in SMEs possible. The report contains many of the above elements. It has also been amended by the Green Group with an action plan to guarantee minimum incomes in SMEs to combat poverty and social exclusion of workers. I will vote in favor with conviction.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: in writing. - There is no doubt that many European Union countries are still struggling with social problems resulting from the financial crisis, in particular high unemployment. In the case of other countries, especially in Central and Eastern Europe, the relatively low level of prosperity is due to historical reasons. The European Pillar of Social Rights proposed by the European Commission aims to support employment and social progress. With the existing large differences in the level of social security in the 28 EU countries, it is difficult to imagine developing detailed solutions for social policy at the Community level, and not at the level of individual Member States. Therefore, I am afraid that the Commission's initiative in its current form, despite its lofty assumptions, may in practice lead to a breach or even allow EU countries to restrict the fundamental freedoms of the single market: the movement of workers and the provision of services. Such actions, already carried out under the pretext of fighting the so-called "Social dumping", are completely inconsistent with the idea, principles and regulations established for the creation of the single market. They are not in the interest of the poorer EU member states, which must have a chance to catch up quickly, especially those that arose after World War II and became permanent during the "Cold War" period.

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE)
text: signed up.- The European Union needs a European pillar of social rights.But this social pillar must include a small number of social rights regulated at European level.In essence, social rights and policies must be in the decision-making power of each Member State.We consider that the determinants of social rights and policies are specific to each Member State: demographic change, level of economic development, traditions in social policies, etc.I believe that what is to be defined at European level goes far beyond what is necessary.

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu (S&D)
text: signed up. - In the context of sustainable development and exponential change in all socio-economic fields, the European Union must take rapid and visible responsibility for the growing inequalities in the European Community, rising unemployment, work-life imbalances , poverty among children, young people and the elderly, as well as the systems needed to maintain human health, safety and dignity. Especially since, worldwide, the European Union has high standards (not only) in terms of social assistance and work. This is because the developed European social model is the most advanced in the history of the world, which gives it and entrusts the European Union with the role of leader in the field of social rights. It is therefore welcome to reflect on the existing social acquis, which brings together national parliaments, governments, EU institutions, civil society and the social partners, with a view to developing a pillar of social rights that integrates social protection forms and social services. Obviously, the implementation of such a pillar requires tools (including financial), public social investment, mechanisms, legislation and policies converging with economic, social and employment, so as to lead to increasing the well-being of each European entity (especially employees and workers with “atypical” employment contracts).

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: in writing. - Modern Europe has the most advanced social model in its history. It has ensured decent working conditions, comprehensive social protection and sufficiently good public services for the majority of the population. The social model has also helped to significantly increase productivity and European competitiveness. It is essential that the welfare structures of our state keep pace with demographic change, technology, globalization and the recent significant increase in social inequality. At the same time, we must repair the damage caused by the long economic crisis, the consequences of which we are still feeling. The EU must once again become a backbone in this regard, strengthening the Member States and helping them to promote the European social model, in particular by supporting the family and its role in society. Only in this way can the demographic decline on our continent be combated effectively. European economic governance needs to be further reshaped to take greater account of social indicators and economic policy-making. As far as the euro area is concerned, the right cycle needs to be launched to create quality jobs that provide people with economic security and employment. Higher employment and higher levels of social protection would also increase the amount of revenue collected, thus increasing the sustainability of public welfare, and this is an important challenge we are now facing.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - Europe is slowly recovering from the crisis, but social inequality remains very high in some places. I welcome the Commission's efforts to eliminate these inequalities through a new pillar of social rights. Only on a well-off economy that is able to respond to shocks and adapt to them can we build a just social system. A healthy economy will bring a regulated market with fair working conditions, adequate and sustainable social protection, equal opportunities and access to the labor market. Regardless of the fact that we want greater unification, the principle of subsidiarity must be observed, according to which the Member States have the possibility to regulate certain areas themselves, such as the minimum wage, maternity leave, social benefits, etc. The European Union needs a strong social model based on real, accessible and understandable measures. The Commission has covered a number of pressing issues in its proposal, but it is essential to ensure that the proposed measures are implemented so that not just letters are left on paper.

name: Kathleen Van Brempt (S&D)
text: written. - I welcome the European Pillar of Social Rights as an important initiative to bring about a more social union and usher our social model into the 21st century. It is an opportunity to set up concrete actions that citizens perceive to benefit them. I am thinking of the right to a minimum income, a package of social rights that apply to all workers (employees and the self-employed), the right to education, a child guarantee to ensure that fewer children grow up in poverty or social exclusion. This requires not only legislative initiatives, but also additional resources. In addition to concrete initiatives, and at least as important, the Social Pillar must ensure that social policy is placed on an equal footing with economic and monetary policy. Analogous to the fiscal compact, which obliges member states to keep their budgets in balance, a Social Pact must be concluded. This Social Pact must not only anchor the major principles of the Social Pillar in European legislation, but must also allow member states to be obliged to take their social policy seriously. After all, poor scores in the field of (youth) unemployment, (child) poverty, etc. are at least as problematic as poor budget figures.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on Indonesia, namely the case of Hosea Jeimo, Ishmael Alua and the Governor of Jakarta (2017/2506 (RSP)).

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri
text: author. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, last month over 500 people were arrested and later released for participating in several simultaneous peaceful demonstrations held in different regions of Indonesia, notably in the province of West Papua. Hosea Yeimo and Ismael Alua, two young activists belonging to a student organization, were arrested and charged with rebellion only to be released with a ban on leaving the city. In Jakarta, on the other hand, Governor Ahok, belonging to the Christian minority, the first non-Muslim governor elected, is on trial for the crime of blasphemy. This resolution calls for Indonesia not only to review its position in the cases mentioned, but to take action to protect human rights, with the immediate abolition of the death penalty still in force. We hope that in the high-level dialogue between Indonesia and the European Union these issues will not only be dealt with but are being resolved.

name: Bas Belder
text: Author.- Unity in diversity, Indonesia's national motto.Tolerance between all groups, cultures and religions.It is the great responsibility of the European Union, including ours here, to address all Indonesian authorities strongly and persistently in the context of mutual relations, because even very thoughtful circles in the archipelago, I heard yesterday, fearserious that the national pendulum is moving towards Islamic fundamentalism and radicalism, that is, intolerance.A sad illustration of this is the trial of the current governor of Jakarta.His Christian and Chinese background are the obvious motives of the prosecutors.Already on the first day of the trial against Ahok, his Muslim opponents intimidated the judges, the opposite of unity in diversity!That is why we must ring the alarm with all democratic forces in Indonesia.

name: Barbara Lochbihler
text: Author. - Madam President! Some colleagues in this House are interfering with the human rights urgency. They consider it pointless, a disruptive factor in relations with the countries addressed. However, if you look into these countries with open eyes, you can easily see that our urgencies are noticed by governments, parliaments, the media and civil society. I am therefore particularly pleased that, in the resolution before us, the two arrested members of the West Papua National Committees, Hosea Yeimo and Ismael Alua, were released while the resolution was being drafted. The next step, however, must be to drop the charges against the two of them for purely peaceful political activities. They are not isolated cases. There has been reports of a sharp rise in political arrests in West Papua. Freedom of assembly and expression must be guaranteed, and laws such as Articles 106 and 110 of the Indonesian Penal Code must not be used to criminalize peaceful political activity. (The speaker agreed to answer a question about the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Mrs Lochbihler!Hasn't the Netherlands recommended that West Papua actually belongs to Papua New Guinea and that the island of New Guinea forms a unit since the colony was dissolved?Hasn't the indigenous population been forced to move away from West Papua for decades, which has basically led to the indigenous population now forming a minority?

name: Barbara Lochbihler
text: Draftsman answering a question about the blue card procedure.- I'm not an Indonesia expert.But that's also what I read.Only, I think we position ourselves there.Whether we are in favor of independence or not is beyond the scope of a discussion on human rights policy.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: author. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, good morning Commissioner, the government authorities in Indonesia have adopted an increasingly repressive policy towards opponents, activists and representatives of minorities in the area, particularly against the Papuan community. In fact, several NGOs have been documented arbitrary arrests following peaceful protests and consequent ill-treatment by prison guards. The governor of Jakarta also paid the price for this policy, condemned on charges of blasphemy, a pretext aimed at discrediting and eliminating an uncomfortable person. The complexity of the case and the vastness of the operations should make us reflect on the actual extent of Indonesian multi-religiousness, which could even affect the country's future democracy. We cannot forget that Indonesia is an important trading partner of ours and it is therefore essential that bilateral economic and trade relations are accompanied by a firm demand for improvement in the internal human rights situation, starting with the cases discussed in this resolution and including minority rights. The European Union must constantly monitor what is happening in Indonesia and use commercial leverage to protect human rights. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8)))

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Dear colleague, as I know very well you are a lawyer, do you not think that the European Union should intervene in order that Indonesia immediately repeal its blasphemy laws, the electronic information and transaction law, and the provisions in its criminal code relating to rebellion?

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: Answer to a "blue card" question.- Yes, Hon.Frunzulică, I agree, should intervene, the European Union should use what is in its power from the diplomatic point of view to try, in fact, to put pressure on the government to change these laws.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: author. - Madam President, Indonesia is a very large country, the largest Muslim country in the world, rich in a great cultural and religious diversity recognized by its Constitution. Indonesia has made significant strides towards democracy since the fall of General Suharto. However, sources of concern remain. This is the case with the crackdown on Papuan peace activists. Hosea Yeimo and Ismael Alua are the symbols. The same is true with the instrumentalization of archaic blasphemy laws, especially against the governor of Jakarta, on the eve of local elections. We could also talk about President Jokowi's heavy record in terms of executions, mainly for drug trafficking, of which the case of Serge Atlaoui is symbolic, but also violence against LGBTI people, or child labor. Finally, it is time, as requested by the Indonesian Human Rights Commission, to open the file of the massacres of 1965, during which hundreds of thousands of Communists or supposedly such lost their lives, and while their descendants continue to be persecuted in Indonesia. So, yes, the dialogue on human rights makes perfect sense in this country.

name: Frédérique Ries
text: author. - Madam President, Hosea Yeimo and Ismael Alua, the two Papuan peace activists who are behind our debate this morning, have indeed been released but their fate remains worrying. Accused of rebellion, they now face life imprisonment. It is therefore essential that the European External Action Service keep up the pressure. This is precisely what we are asking for in our resolution. I would have appreciated that our common text mentions and demands so clearly, precisely and firmly the lifting of the charges against the governor of Jakarta, whose fate has been mentioned. Basuki Tjahaja Purnama, a Christian of Chinese origin, is unfairly accused of blasphemy by radical Islamists. Madam President, the good relations that the European Union legitimately maintains with Indonesia - and I am not forgetting here that this country was one of the very first to be struck by the Islamist attacks - should not prevent us from continue to be demanding on the issue of respect for human rights.

name: Jeroen Lenaers
text: author. – Madam President, the ties between the EU and Indonesia go back many years, and they have never been stronger than today: we have the adoption of the EU-Indonesia Partnership and Cooperation Agreement, the negotiations on the FTA and, last but not least, we had the relaunch of the European Parliament-Indonesia Friendship Group earlier this year. As part of our friendship, which is based on shared values of human rights, democracy and governance, united in diversity, it is crucial that we are able to discuss matters that concern us with each other. That is exactly the point of this resolution here today: we are concerned about the arrest and prosecution of peaceful demonstrators, concerned about the resumption of capital punishment, and concerned about the blasphemy case against Governor Ahok. We cannot stress enough the need to protect all human rights, particularly for minorities: freedom of belief, freedom of expression and freedom of peaceful assembly. It is our duty to continue, and we look forward to doing that with the Indonesian authorities in the framework of the human rights dialogue and beyond to make sure that the ‘united in diversity’ values that we both share will remain a crucial part of Indonesian society.

name: Pavel Svoboda
text: for the PPE Group.- One aspect of this case is freedom of religion.This must not be limited, for example, by the existence of anti-blasphemy laws, which can be used not only against expressions of religious faith, but also more widely abused against the exercise of freedom of expression.The European Union should therefore certainly call on the Indonesian Government to promote religious tolerance in its country and to defend human rights.The European Union should therefore also act in accordance with the European Parliament's recommendation to the Council of June 2013, which recommends that the provision of development assistance be made conditional on respect for freedom of religion.Over the last 10 years, the European Union has provided at least half a billion euros to Indonesia, and the continuation of this assistance should therefore be conditional on respect for the human rights of all Indonesians, regardless of religion or origin.

name: Ana Gomes
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group.- Indonesia is a strategic partner for the European Union.It proves that Islam and democracy are compatible.And it is for everyone a reference in the fight against extremism due to the experience in promoting a tolerant and united society in diversity.As friendly and loyal partners, we want, through this resolution, to encourage the Indonesian authorities to take steps to protect the rights of all peaceful activists and Protestants, especially those calling for social justice and basic freedoms in the Papua region, asHosea Yeimo and Ismael Alua, already released, but subject to legal proceedings.We hope to see unsuccessful attempts to intimidate politicians by certain groups that claim to be more defenders than everyone in the defense of Islam. We hope to see Indonesia repeal blasphemy laws and suspend the application of the death penalty again.

name: Diane James (NI).
text: – Madam President, Indonesia is a prime example of where voters’ high hopes of an improvement in preceding government human rights failures might be addressed, might be righted and might be improved. But that has not been the case, and as we’ve all noted this morning, victimisation, persecution, denial of the free voice and inter-society violence continues unabated. However, care should be taken, and I do not agree with those of my colleagues who this morning have called on the EU to intervene in this situation. It is very complex, and a continent half a world away should not be interfering in a situation which should be dealt with by the geo-political grouping ASEAN, but should leave it for Asian countries surrounding Indonesia to resolve. We, the European Union, have a habit of intervening – intervening in the wrong way, as the sanctions against Russia have shown; we’ve called, in instances, for political isolation; we’ve even called for active military intervention. All of those have shown that EU intervention doesn’t work, shouldn’t be used, and shouldn’t be allowed in this instance.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - I want to support the motion for a resolution tabled here by my colleagues. I believe that human rights violations in the world need to be pointed out, even in countries that are strategic partners of the European Union. Indonesia is certainly a key partner of the European Union, but if Indonesia is a partner and receives financial assistance from the European Union, then we also have a moral right to criticize the human rights situation in that country. The two cases that have been mentioned here and because of which the human rights problem in Indonesia is on the table today need to be emphasized. These are Papuan activists, that is one thing, and they are the governor of Jakarta. Both cases are about how freedom of speech in Indonesia is relativized and recently suppressed. It is also to be criticized that this country has restored the death penalty, which is something that the European Union strongly disagrees with, and the death penalty is unfortunately being used in this country. So this resolution today is, I think, a good guide for the Commission's action towards Indonesia.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the latest events from the world’s largest Muslim majority democracy give rise to concerns about whether its hard-earned record of tolerance is in danger. Although the words of Ahok, the governor of Jakarta, may have been ill-considered and rash, charging him with blasphemy seems to be an excessive measure. Also, giving in to Islamist hardliners in such matters of freedom of expression represents a dangerous slippery slope and also risks reigniting the communal clashes and anti-minority pogroms that are still in recent memory. I sincerely hope that, for the sake of promoting a tolerant society, Indonesia will be wise enough to change course and avoid imposing restrictions on the right to freedom of expression which go beyond the provisions of the international human rights obligations it subscribed to.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). - Madam President, I would like to congratulate you on your election and I would like to say that I support the resolution that I have signed, noting that on the occasion of the accusation against the governor of Jakarta for blasphemy, as well as the arrest of Yeimo and Alua for their participation in peaceful demonstrations in Indonesia, we observe that human rights violations are on the agenda in this country. In particular, the Christian ruler of Jakarta made a statement that challenged the interpretation given by some Muslim theologians to a passage of the Koran, leading to the accusation of blasphemy, which in Indonesia can be punished by five years in prison. At the same time, two young people, Yeimo and Alua, after their arrest for participating in demonstrations, were released, but now they continue to be charged and thus face possible life imprisonment. It is therefore necessary, firstly, for the Indonesian government to drop the charges against Yeimo and Alua and the governor of Jakarta, secondly, to respect the human rights of the citizens of this country and, thirdly, to fight corruption immediately.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (ENF).
text: - Madam President, knowing a little about the region, I would like to point out to my colleagues the exploitation which is made, in the manner of the "color revolutions", of the words of the Christian governor of Jakarta, Ahok, in order to stir up the'Islamism.And it is the work of outside powers.If it had not been for the coordinated intervention of two other external powers, the aim of weakening this country in order to set up radical Islamism would have been obtained by certain madmen who, in fact, from the outside, support the'radical Islam.I therefore ask my colleagues to realize that behind the events there is also manipulation and the use of Islam for political ends.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we have dealt with Indonesia on other occasions to demand a moratorium on the death penalty and to protest the violations of human rights in the country. Today we ask the Indonesian authorities with greater determination for respect for human rights and a halt to the disproportionate use of force. We demand respect for human rights, rights such as those violated by Hosea Yeimo and Ismael Alua, two political activists arrested for their peaceful political activities on charges of rebellion, under the Indonesian penal code. Even if they were released on bail, the two, who declared themselves prisoners of conscience, face a sentence of up to life imprisonment for a crime of opinion. We cannot fail to express concern at the continuing arrests of peaceful protesters who are detained only for exercising their rights to freedom of expression and assembly. The European Union must strengthen cooperation with Indonesia on a number of issues, certainly on the fight against terrorism, but also on the rule of law and respect for human rights.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all I would like to thank the authors of this resolution for their initiative and all colleagues for this comprehensive discussion. Our relations with Indonesia are friendly and close. They develop within the solid framework of the EU-Indonesia Partnership and Cooperation Agreement. In the last couple of months relations between the European Union and Indonesia have advanced in an impressive manner. Last April in Jakarta we launched the ministerial strategic dialogue. A few days later, we welcomed President Widodo to Brussels for the first ever visit of an Indonesian President to the European Union institutions. The first round of negotiations on a Comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement with Indonesia took place in September. In June we held the sixth session of our bilateral human rights dialogue and in November we organised the first Joint Committee under the EU-Indonesia Partnership and Cooperation Agreement. November also witnessed the reactivation of the EP-Indonesia parliamentary friendship group. We see Indonesia as an essential partner. With a quarter of a billion inhabitants, Indonesia is one of the largest democracies in the world. The EU values Indonesia, with its emphasis on pluralism and tolerance, as a model for other countries in the region and beyond.  The two young Papuans referred to by the honourable Members were arrested on 19 December for helping to organise demonstrations throughout the Indonesian provinces of Papua and West Papua. They were charged with treason and secession and were granted temporary suspension of detention on 11 January.  Indonesia and the European Union have discussed the situation in Papua and West Papua on a regular basis in our bilateral human rights dialogue, including during the last meeting, which took place in June. In this context, the European Union has consistently raised concerns about restrictions to Freedom of Expression and Freedom of Peaceful Assembly in the provinces of Papua and West Papua and called on Indonesia to invite relevant UN bodies to visit the country. We have welcomed also President Widodo’s announcement of May 2015 to release all the Papuan prisoners imprisoned for peaceful protest. Indeed, reports from civil society show that the number of such prisoners has decreased from two years ago. This definitely indicates that the Widodo administration is delivering on its promise.  The ongoing trial against the Jakarta Governor who is accused of blasphemy has triggered extensive debate among Indonesians about the role of minorities in the country, as well as about religious tolerance and pluralism, which are at the heart of the Indonesian state and society. Indonesia and the European Union are closely engaged in an ongoing exchange on these and other issues pertaining to Freedom of Religion or Belief and Freedom of Expression. Please be assured that the European Union will continue to use every opportunity, including the next EU-Indonesia human rights dialogue, to continue to raise the situation in Papua and, of course, the issue of religious freedom, with our Indonesian counterparts.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place today.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing.- The human rights dimension plays a fundamental role in the development of future relations between the European Union and Indonesia, which is why the following motion for a resolution is committed to this.Specifically, I consider it very serious that, despite the government's commitments, some minorities in Indonesia, including the LGBT community, are still discriminated against, and it is equally serious that the death penalty has been reintroduced.Furthermore, the European Union must commit itself to strongly demand the release of the numerous political prisoners who have been imprisoned during the frequent peaceful protests, as well as the adoption of all necessary measures to ensure the creation of suitable conditions for the exercise of freedom of speech.and peaceful demonstration.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Today we discussed the human rights situation in Indonesia. Indonesia is the world's fourth most populous country, the third largest democracy, the largest predominantly Muslim country with millions of other religions and a diverse society with 255 million people of different ethnicities, languages ​​and cultures. In the motion for a resolution, we state that we very much appreciate the relationship between the EU and Indonesia. The EU and Indonesia work closely together on a wide range of issues. The EU and Indonesia have agreed to implement concrete cooperation projects in a number of areas, including access to justice and criminal policy, the fight against violent extremism and business law. At the same time, however, we are concerned about the growing intolerance of ethnic, religious and sexual minorities in Indonesia, and we condemn all acts of violence against and persecution and intimidation and impunity of those who commit such acts.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on the Central African Republic (2017/2507 (RSP)).

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri
text: author. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, over the past year the situation of persistent tension and violence in the Central African Republic has shown no signs of improvement. The killing of the two peacekeepers and the wounding of a third, all operators of the UN MINUSCA mission, are episodes that demonstrate how the violation of human rights and international humanitarian law is still at the center of the crisis that the country has been facing since 2012 . Although we have already recalled in this Chamber the need for a clear intervention by the European Union and the African Union, through the establishment of a functioning and indispensable judicial system to be able to carry out an accurate investigation into all cases of violence, crimes and crimes, with this resolution today we confirm and relaunch as the European Parliament our attention and our commitment so that the Central African Republic can effectively overcome this state of crisis and start a new season of democracy, respect for human rights and positive growth.

name: Charles Tannock
text: author. – Madam President, the election of President Touadéra last year was an important step in trying to rebuild the Central African Republic after the outbreak of a very violent civil war in 2012. The UN mission there, which now has over 10 000 troops on the ground, is continuing to enforce the peace, but the realities of daily life remain bleak. Law and order beyond the confines of the capital Bangui is patchy, and acts of violence are executed with impunity. Recent attacks targeting UN peacekeepers are a grave concern. With more than 2.2 million people in need of humanitarian assistance and nearly half a million IDPs, the need for aid is urgent and cannot be stressed enough. In this regard, I am pleased to know that the European Union is the largest donor to CAR and I welcome the multi-donor EU trust fund established in 2014. The launch last year of the EU CSDP training mission is also a welcome step. The creation of competent and professional security forces is vital for the long-term stability of that landlocked country and a key part of ultimately transferring peace—keeping operations back to the government. I am also very concerned about the activities of the Lord’s Resistance Army and the fact that despite Joseph Kony being indicted for war crimes, they are still now trying to find a foot in that country. I will conclude by saying that I hope that these efforts can contribute towards disarming the militias and restoring stability to that landlocked country.

name: Bodil Valero
text: Author. - Madam President! The Central African Republic has long had major problems. There is a lot to worry about. Both in terms of security and in terms of poverty issues. At the same time, it is also the case that great progress has been made recently. On the one hand, the country has conducted elections, and on the other hand, a new constitution has been adopted in a referendum, and as far as I know it has been free and fair. The president also looks to be doing a good job at the moment. Therefore, we have some difficulty in understanding why we are currently treating the Central African Republic as an urgent matter. There are very many other urgent matters that we do not address here and which I would find perhaps even more urgent. However, there is very good in the resolution as well. I would like to highlight in particular the call on international companies to stop fueling this conflict and human rights violations through their trade in illegal diamonds and other illegally extracted natural resources.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: author. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the civil war in the Central African Republic has been going on since 2004, causing death, destruction and an ever-increasing number of refugees. 2017 has already seen the death of three UN peacekeepers and the situation is increasingly precarious, so much so that in some areas humanitarian workers have been forced to suspend their activities. The state has growing difficulties in maintaining order in the territory and is unable to bring to justice all those who are taking advantage of this crisis to commit crimes and abuses. In a previous speech I had already highlighted, for example, the heavy contribution of Western companies which, in order to keep their business, did not scruple to support both warring factions in an attempt to prolong and maintain the state of war. in the Central African Republic. The European Parliament has spoken on this issue several times and an ad hoc conference was held on 17 November. Now is the time to act, to apply the measures contained in this resolution to take a decisive step towards lasting peace and a definitive return to the status quo ante bellum.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez
text: Author.- Madam President, women's human rights are also human rights.The right of women not to be violated is a human right and, therefore, in the face of complaints of violations in the Central African Republic by French soldiers and blue helmets, I want to appeal to the High Representative and the States, namely theFrench state, to end impunity for any military who is an aggressor, who is a sex offender.We also want to express our deep concern about the opacity and the filing by the French authorities of complaints against their soldiers for rape in the Central African Republic.We ask that no complaints be filed and that those that have been filed be reopened.We also call for an independent and transparent investigation and for the truth to be ascertained and for justice to be taken regarding these serious accusations of sexual abuse.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský
text: author. - Violence and repression of the human rights of the population continue to occur in the Central African Republic, despite all the efforts of the local government and the international military mission MINUSCA. They have been trying to improve the local tragic situation for a long time, which is why I am glad that all the factions agreed on the text of this resolution. Not only are dozens of innocent civilians killed, including children, but we also see frequent raids on military convoys. And that says nothing more than continued instability in this country. There is a need to further appeal to local authorities to work hard to punish all perpetrators and to build a stable and fair justice system. Only in this way can the overall situation in the Central African Republic improve. The European Union's task is not only to draw attention to ongoing problems, but also to continue its role as a major donor of humanitarian aid, helping the poorest people in the world's second poorest country. This also requires the willingness of the Government of the Central African Republic. A willingness to finally end the suffering of its citizens, a willingness to restore order and, last but not least, a willingness to ensure that all human rights are guaranteed, without exception.

name: Cristian Dan Preda
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, congratulations on your re-election. I welcome our debate today on the situation in the Central African Republic. We have not had such discussions in our Parliament for some time. However, it is essential to show that we are interested in this issue and that the increase in violations of international humanitarian and human rights law, including arbitrary executions, sexual violence and all kinds of attacks against the civilian population, does not leave us indifferent. On the contrary, we strongly condemn these serious crimes and with regard to the most recent attacks against MINUSCA forces which claimed the lives of two Moroccan peacekeepers and one from Bangladesh, we express our sympathy to their families and their families. governments. The Central African Republic must remain on our radar despite the significant progress made and the holding of elections marking the success of the political transition. The country unfortunately remains plagued by instability and sporadic violence. We must continue to support and accompany on-going efforts to promote peace and reconciliation.

name: Nicola Caputo
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I strongly condemn the violations of human rights and international humanitarian law which are taking place in the Central African Republic by the Muslim rebels Seleka and the Christian Anti-Balaka militia. I urge the government of the Central African Republic to launch impartial investigations into all violations, prosecuting those responsible, perhaps establishing a special criminal court. It is imperative that the government of the Central African Republic invests significantly, with the support of the international community, in the judicial system, with the aim of rebuilding the courts and police forces and thereby putting an end to the current widespread impunity. I call on the African authorities to implement, with the support of its international partners, the National Plan for Restoration and Peacebuilding, in particular through capacity building of national security forces, disarmament, demobilization and reintegration of groups armed. Finally, with regard to the exploitation and illicit trafficking of natural resources, the creation, by the United Nations and within the framework of MINUSCA, of a special unit to combat the smuggling of diamonds, timber, gold and ivory would be appropriate.

name: Mark Demesmaeker
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - One look at the history of the Central African Republic tells us that the country and its people have been plagued for decades by ethnic and religious violence, dictators and gross violations of human rights. The population deserves better. We are therefore pleased with the peaceful election of President Touadera. But the situation in the CAR is not yet what it should be. Too often, news of rape, bankruptcy and famine reaches us. We therefore fully support the present resolution. First of all, of course, we want all those guilty of violence to be held accountable for violations of humanitarian law. The government really needs to work on that. Also of the reform of the legal system, together with the international community. We also support the talks between the various armed groups led by the UN. We also call on all international partners to fulfill their financial obligations so that the terrible famine can be tackled structurally. Half of the Central African population is starving, this is a shame. We really cannot leave these people to their own devices.

name: Louis Michel
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Madam President, my political group has decided not to co-sign the resolution on the CAR. What we are proposing to you in this joint resolution, basically, whether you like it or not, is to sanction the record of a democratically elected government, a little less than a year ago, which is trying to create a sacred union with a view to building a dynamic of unification that meets the needs of peace, development and security, through a permanent and inclusive dialogue. We all welcomed, on the occasion of the international donors' conference, which was held in Brussels, the efforts made by this same government and by the National Assembly to build peace and reconciliation in a fragile and uncertain context. . In the European Parliament, on the sidelines of this conference, we expressed our support for President Touadéra and congratulated the President of the Assembly, Karim Meckassoua, for the broad and inclusive composition of his delegation and for the visible efforts they are making to rebuild their state. I would like to recall that the CAR has signed the Protocol on Torture, adopted legislation on gender equality and accelerated legislation on the new judicial architecture provided for in the Constitution. We must, of course, invest in the security sector, as we know. State authority must be reestablished over the whole territory to be able to fight impunity. But the most urgent problem at present is the establishment of transitional justice that is planned. I would like to point out that the procedure for the selection of international judges for the Special Criminal Court has just been launched at the United Nations. Therefore, instead of voting for a text that sends a negative signal to the international community just one week before the meeting in Bangui between the European Commission and the Central African authorities to set up the structure of coordination of aid, we would do well to invite President Touadéra and the President of the National Assembly here in the European Parliament to debate with us.

name: Louis Aliot
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Madam President, dear colleagues, a few months ago, the transition chaired by Catherine Samba-Panza ended with the observation of questionable financial practices and indecent systemic clientelism. Faithful to its tradition of protecting populations, France fortunately undertook, in 2013, successfully to put an end to the massacres of the Islamic minority Seleka against the majority Christians in the country. I take this opportunity to congratulate the French army for its action under particularly difficult conditions. In a country where the state controls only a small part of its territory and where political parties are formed on ethnic and religious lines, everyone has turned a blind eye to the questionable legality of the elections. Unfortunately, this is becoming a habit in Africa today. The population suffers from a state of growing food insecurity and survives only thanks to a few NGOs. Since the inauguration of the new president, nothing has changed, nothing works: no justice, no health, no education. Blood criminals and economic predators still hold their sway. Diamonds still supply the places of Antwerp or Dubai with well-known Central Africans at the head of these mafia networks which use Cameroon and Sudan as crossing points. The mining sites are controlled by rebellions which benefit from political complicity. Today, only funding from the IMF and the European Union can pay the officials who perpetuate this corrupt and doomed system. It is feared that the Central African Republic could become the center of rebellions in Central Africa and further fuel migratory flows within Africa. Dear colleagues, denying reality does not improve the rule of law. Africa is asking for peace, stability and cooperation. Do you want to be credible? Put an end to trafficking and punish at home, in Europe, those who profit from these riches to the detriment of the development of these countries.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI). - Madam President, I also congratulate you on your re-election. The protection of human rights is an obligation of everyone who feels that he is primarily a human being. In this sense, the European Union's sensitivity to the protection of human rights in all European countries and, in this case, in the Central African Republic, where human rights are actually violated, is right. At this point, however, we must point out the hypocrisy of the European Union's leading circle, which deals selectively with human rights abuses and invokes only those that serve political expediencies. How were the human rights of those who, because of the wars, forced to flee their home countries protected, an escape which the European Union, while it could, did not want to prevent? How were and are the human rights of all those who Turkey, with the tolerance of the European Union, sends hundreds of thousands to Greece, a country financially damaged by the austerity of the memoranda that can not serve them and therefore suffer there? How were the human rights, even the very right to life, of those who died of the cold in Greece, Serbia and the other countries of the European Union protected? Finally, how were the human rights of those who drowned in the Mediterranean protected? The European Union is responsible for these deaths and the aid it now wants to offer does not relieve it of its enormous responsibilities.

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta (PPE).
text: - Madam President! Commissioner! The Central African Republic, the penultimate country in the United Nations Human Development Ranking, is facing a growing crime as well as a difficult humanitarian situation. Despite the successful elections last February and the stabilization of the country after the coup d'état and the sectarian civil war, attacks by rebels against civilians, including ethnic minorities, have intensified in recent months and a sense of lawlessness has increased. Acts of aggression towards employees of the MINUSCA mission and humanitarian organizations effectively prevent the provision of aid to over two million citizens in need of this aid. It is important that the CAR's authorities continue their efforts to disarm and reintegrate members of the armed groups as well as to establish the rule of law and an efficient justice system. In this context, close cooperation of the authorities of this country with the European Union, the World Bank and the United Nations is of great importance.

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge (S&D).
text: - Madam President, strengthening dialogue and reconciliation is the way to restore lasting peace in the Central African Republic. President Touadéra has been working there since his election under conditions of extreme fragility, due to a system worn out by decades of civil war. I believe that we have the duty and the responsibility to support the efforts of this new democratically elected government in order to obtain the strengthening of an administrative structure and of the state. We regret all the massacres of populations that have been perpetrated. We also strongly condemn the deadly attacks against MINUSCA forces engaged in peacekeeping operations. I believe that through our support, we also expect the new authorities to strengthen political and economic governance, a separation of powers and the fight against impunity, measures that the democratically elected institutions have already put in place. The European Parliament will continue to support all the efforts of the new government and will ensure that the conditions for normalcy are restored in the country.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - Congratulations on your re-election and I would like to comment on the report, which I also signed.The situation in the Central African Republic is very serious, and our report is addressed to the Government of the Central African Republic, as well as to the United Nations and the European Commission.Civilians are dying in this country and human rights are not protected.In its report, the European Parliament commends the efforts of the Government of the Central African Republic, which, with the help of international troops, is working to calm the situation and protect civilians, but these efforts have not been sufficiently successful.There is great violence, insecurity and hundreds of thousands of refugees in the surrounding countries.Of course, these refugees are looking for safety.This also applies to the European Union, because these refugees may also be refugees looking for a way to Europe.The European Union supports financial stabilization in the Central African Republic, and we support the government of that country.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD).
text: - Madam President, congratulations on your re-election, ladies and gentlemen, a real war between militias and gangs has been raging in the Central African Republic for several years, which unfortunately has taken on the religious and ethnic contours that we know well. At the same time, illicit trafficking also rages and the State now has difficulty in having real control of the territory, which is now limited, as is its ability to guarantee control of public order. Here, as elsewhere, those who rage and those who still attack the state order are above all the logic of divide and rule of multinational groups and companies, including European ones, which, caught by fever and blinded by the pursuit of the precious resources of this country. market, in fact, risk leading to a destabilization that could over time explode in the entire region and in the entire area. It is time to demand communion and that there is justice for the victims of torture, murders and constant attacks, that there is an opportunity for these people to emerge from the state of famine that endangers tens of thousands of lives and that violations human rights have an end, as well as these illicit trafficking which is undermining the centrality of the state. It is time for the international community and the European Union to really do their duty.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE).
text: - After decades of underdevelopment and lack of stability, we in the Central African Republic are finally witnessing greater efforts by the authorities to promote peace and reconciliation.Nevertheless, the country is still facing an unstable situation resulting from various conflicts across the country.To improve the human rights situation, we need more intensive and effective cooperation from all actors, including the UN and the European Union.In this light, we must support the work of the International Organization of La Francophonie, which has been fighting for many years to improve the situation in the Central African Republic.Without its efforts to strengthen democracy and the rule of law (it also supported the establishment of a national human rights commission, among other things), the situation in the Central African Republic would certainly have been much worse.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I am grateful that this house has maintained its intention on the Central African Republic which, as has already been said, is at a very critical moment in its history and where the European Union has potential to make an important and positive difference.  Human rights are an important element of our approach, including our diplomatic dialogue. With the help of the international community, the Central African Republic has made important progress in the last couple of years, after one of the most painful periods in its history. Credible presidential and parliamentary elections have provided the national authorities with legitimacy and a clear mandate to break with the past and lead the country towards recovery and peace. Many challenges remain and the Central African Republic is still in a very fragile situation with very limited state control, unfortunately. Insecurity continues to be widespread. In the past months we have seen a resurge of clashes between armed groups, again causing civilian deaths, new displacements, and serious human rights violations which are mostly the consequences of armed violence. The killing of three blue helmets at the beginning of January was a sad reminder of this insecurity, as well as a reminder of the importance of the work of MINUSCA, which as you know the European Union fully supports.  The ongoing fragility also hampers the much-needed access for humanitarian and development actors to some areas. President Touadéra speaks with strong conviction about the need for national conciliation and justice, and his government has taken the first steps to establish a dialogue with the armed groups in order to disarm, demobilise, reintegrate and repatriate them. We need to encourage this process and make sure that both pillars – reconciliation and justice – receive appropriate attention, as true reconciliation will not be possible without rendering justice for serious violations of human rights. Improving the capacity of the justice system, as well as reforming the security forces are therefore key.  The European Union, as the Central African Republic’s most important partner, continues to support the government in these efforts. The European Union has invested more than EUR 500 million in the Central African Republic in the last three years, and the Brussels Conference for the Central African Republic last November, co-chaired by the High Representative, led to more than 2 billion pledges, 750 million of them from the European Union, and our Member States are as usual the largest donors. I attended the conference myself and I saw the strong commitment of all those present to make a difference. The challenge now is to deliver and effectively implement the Central African Republic’s national plan. This is the crucial challenge for the national authorities and, of course, for the international community and us, the European Union. Addressing human rights in transitional justice is at the centre of the European Union’s approach in the Central African Republic. In our political dialogue with the authorities as well as with regional and international partners, we continue to advocate ending impunity for human rights violations in the Central African Republic and improving the protection of the most vulnerable groups, among them, unfortunately, women, children and minorities.  2017 will be a decisive year for the Central African Republic. The European Union stands ready to continue our support to put the country firmly on the path of peace and reconstruction.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place today.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR)
text: in writing. - The RCA is one of the poorest countries in the world, which has not been able to build a stable statehood since it liberated itself from colonial rule. The problems that affect the population of the Central African Republic embody the most serious challenges: hunger, poverty, droughts, floods, land depletion, monstrous religious and ethnic conflicts, the uncontrolled escalation of which has led to mass crimes, murders, crimes, and robberies. Christians became particular victims of the conflict, especially after the entry of Selek's troops and Boko Haram factions. The phenomenon of terrorism is increasing, people being washed, weapons and drugs are being washed out, and the exploitation of natural resources is not bringing any benefits to the population of the Central African Republic. The European Union is the largest donor of humanitarian and development aid. It uses UN channels in its activities. The Western presence has not always proved effective. There were also phenomena compromising representatives of peace and stabilization missions. Intensive involvement of EU structures and a well-thought-out aid plan are needed. The EU bridging mission, involving gendarmerie units of the Member States, including Poland, was an undoubted success, but it was too short. After initial organizational problems, the UN mission MINUSCA, which took over from it, allowed the situation to improve to a degree that would allow for presidential elections. The efforts of the entire Western world, of all its democratic institutions, are necessary for the establishment of permanent peace in the CA. I also appreciate the commitment of all religious leaders as well as Polish missionaries who have been present there for many years.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. – The situation in the Central African Republic remains unstable. Although the brutal violence between Seleka rebels and the ‘Anti-balaka’ militia has dropped out of the picture, attacks against civilians (in particular women and children), peacekeepers and humanitarian organisations persist. In addition, the Central African Republic authorities are struggling to re-establish the rule of law in the country and therefore fail to hold accountable before justice those responsible for violence. Therefore, the country’s authorities have to focus on fighting against impunity by increasing protection of witnesses and victims and by adopting without delay a strategy for transnational justice in order to address the legacy of past-fundamental rights violations. In addition, I call on the EU to increase its support for civil society organisations in the country in order to improve documentation of human rights abuses and crimes under international law.

name: David McAllister (PPE)
text: written. - The Central African Republic remains in a difficult position. Despite the peaceful elections in February 2016 and the efforts of President Touadéra to stabilize the country after years of armed conflict, human rights violations are to be lamented on a daily basis. The devious and intolerable attacks on the United Nations blue helmet soldiers - in which three soldiers were killed - are further evidence of the ongoing unstable situation in the country. So that neither the atrocities against the population nor the attacks on peacekeepers recur, the "National Plan for Recovery and Peacebuilding", which was jointly developed by the EU, UN and the Central African government, must be implemented immediately. Among other things, this plan provides for curbing violence in the country through disarmament and the reintegration of former fighters, reorganizing the country's security policy, reforming the judicial system and punishing human rights violations consistently, as well as promoting reconciliation and strengthening social cohesion. Only if the government in Bangui actively works to ensure that Central Africa is not governed by the law of the strongest, but by the strength of the law, can this country - with the help of its international partners - find its way back to normality.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this resolution. It is noteworthy that despite political progress, the CAR is still struggling with instability, insecurity, coercion and occasional unrest. It is therefore essential to address this problem as soon as possible and to put an end to this precarious situation. In particular, reforms should be conducted in accordance with the principles of democratic and economic governance and through constructive dialogue. There is a need for dialogue with armed groups and for the re-establishment of the judicial and criminal chain and the fight against impunity. In addition, the government should initiate expeditious and impartial investigations into all alleged violations of human rights and humanitarian law as soon as possible. Attention should be paid to the humanitarian situation in the country, in particular internally displaced and isolated persons. Not only the EU but also all international donors need to step up their efforts in humanitarian aid. Given that the illegal trade in diamonds and timber and their extraction fuels conflict and finances the armed forces, the CAR authorities need to develop their national strategy to combat the illegal extraction and trade of natural resources as soon as possible.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on the situation in Burundi (2017/2508 (RSP)).

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri
text: author. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, last month the President of Burundi announced that he will run for a fourth term in 2020 and is already making the necessary amendments to overcome the limit of two legislatures imposed by the Constitution. For almost two years now the country has experienced strong repression, following the riots of citizens who had already opposed the third term.
