The serious violations of human rights, the tight control over information and the closure of five civil society organizations, as well as the attitude of the government towards international institutions are of concern. With this resolution we call on the Government of Burundi to release arbitrarily detained persons and to put an end to the acts of intimidation against human rights ombudsmen and journalists. The European Union, together with the African Union and the Security Council, must work to promote dialogue between all parties, find a peaceful solution to the crisis and restore democracy and the rule of law, starting from the Arusha Agreement which helped sustain peace in Burundi for a decade.

name: Mark Demesmaeker
text: Author. - As a former mandate territory of my Member State, Burundi naturally concerns me. Belgium bears a historic responsibility and it strikes me that the country, under President Nkurunziza, continues to slide into an increasingly authoritarian state. The youth division of his political party is guilty of rape, extortion and intimidation. Human rights activists such as Marie-Claudette Kwizera are disappearing and any form of opposition is being crushed. I therefore support this resolution which calls on the African Union, the UN Security Council and our High Representative of the European Union to take further steps against the regime and which draws attention to the fate of the refugees. Our previous efforts already brought a glimmer of hope. For example, seven days after the vote of our previous resolution, journalist Bob Rugurika was released under bail. I am also pleased that the Belgian government has received Pierre Claver Mbonimpa for care after a brutal attack on him in Bujumbura. Today he continues his fight for human rights in Burundi from Belgium. With this in mind, let's continue our work for Burundi and keep the pressure on the regime high.

name: Michèle Rivasi
text: author. - Madam President, as has been indicated, the political situation in Burundi is very worrying, to the point that some observers are worried about the occurrence of genocide. In fact, the country has seen very little respite since gaining independence, and the civil war has opened wounds that are difficult to close. That is why President Nkurunziza's provocations must stop. Indeed, after his second illegitimate election in 2010, he succeeded, in 2015, in a coup by force of a third rigged election, contrary to the Constitution of Burundi and the Arusha Accord. Now he is taunting his people and the international community by announcing a likely fourth term. In fact, he is an outlaw. If the Constitution is the keystone of institutional and political stability, the Arusha agreement is that of social peace, since it rests on pillars supposed to ensure the fair representation of different ethnicities. Today, this guarantee of peace is called into question. I would nevertheless like to point out that Europe has contributed 22 million euros to humanitarian aid for all those who have left Burundi, half of whom are children. Therefore, among the solutions, we really need to restore fundamental rights, allow the return and inclusion of political opposition, and expand targeted sanctions.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: author. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the humanitarian and civil catastrophe that is happening in Burundi has a name and a surname, his name is Pierre Nkurunziza, the current President who, mocking the Constitution and the peace agreements, not only got himself elected for a third term but today he speaks of a fourth election in 2020. What is happening in the Burundian state is frightening. Every time the international community tries to take a few timid steps there is a truly blow for blow response, such as when, on October 19, 2016, Burundi withdrew from the International Criminal Court after the Court itself announced that it had opened a first preliminary investigation. The NGOs have been expelled, I am also talking about the UNIIB or the Ligue Iteka, the oldest in the country, and now every voice of dissent and every voice that rises against this government is constantly silenced. The police and security forces, as well as the terrible Imbonerakure militias are raging with murders, kidnappings, torture, rape and summary arrests and the crisis, which began as a political one, has now taken on clearly ethnic contours by the will of the government itself. . The victims of Tutsi ethnicity are growing exponentially, even a minister even on New Year's Eve. And this in the silence of the international community, so much so that someone spoke of a real "silent genocide" and we instead have the burden of keeping our guard up, of demanding a strong reaction. We owe it to people like Pierre Claver Mbonimpa, whom I had the honor of knowing and also inviting to Rome for an awareness raising event on what is happening in the country. We also owe it to an intervention that must be strong, police forces must be deployed to reduce violence, as an interposition force. We cannot allow that "never again" that we said in Rwanda instead becomes a "again and again" today as today.This also depends on us, if we continue to be so passive and wait for history to take its course, perhaps simply out of forgetfulness or because we think that the priorities are other, we will leave a community and leave these people to themselves and deny that Nobel prize forthe peace that has instead been attributed to the European Union.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: author. - Madam President, Burundi is the poorest country in the world. Since the spring of 2015, he has been sinking into the most serious crisis since the end of the civil war, since the president decided, contrary to his commitments, to run for a third term. He has just announced that he is ready to run for a fourth. It is a downward spiral that nothing seems to be able to stop. Thousands of dead, hundreds of people missing, tortured, hundreds of women victims of sexual violence and, as a result, thousands of refugees. Yes, there is a risk of genocide. Last September, the UN fact-finding mission spoke of possible crimes against humanity and, in response, Burundi decided to leave the ICC. However, his mandate will remain valid for a further year. Yes, everything must be done to re-establish political dialogue and African states have a heavy responsibility in this area. Do they want to act? I have doubts and I fear the worst for the Rwandan people and all those who still dare to face power. Iteka, the oldest human rights league in Africa, is a symbol of this and, in particular, its treasurer who has been missing for several weeks.

name: Pavel Telička
text: author. – Madam President, I need to say that we do not always focus on the right urgencies or the most flagrant cases. Sometimes we even slip up and focus on a country which is making progress and we are more critical than in other cases. But this is the right case. If we look closely into the situation in Burundi, there is hardly a worse case. I am glad that this time we managed to have a good text in the resolution. We found the right language, we seek to tackle impunity and we seek sanctions. May I draw your attention to the fact that, in a country where we see death, torture and rape used as a weapon, targeted violence against women with thousands of people being killed, displaced, etc., I am glad to see that we have a paragraph which calls on the UN Security Council and the International Criminal Court (ICC) to quickly open a full investigation into alleged human rights violations in Burundi, including the danger of genocide within its jurisdiction committed during the recent crisis in the country. I think that this is something that we need to state very clearly.  Finally, I welcome that we are focusing on the targeted sanctions adopted by the EU on 1 October 2015, consistent with the decision taken by the African Union. This is the language that we need to have the courage to use. We cannot be passive, we need to address it and that has to be a strong signal.

name: Joachim Zeller
text: Author. - Madam President! Once again, the situation in Burundi is a topic here in the plenary, since the incumbent President Nkurunziza - one of the richest men in Africa, incidentally in one of the poorest countries in the world - announced in April 2015 that he does not want to leave office the Constitution of Burundi actually imposed it on him. Since then, the country has been ruled by the arbitrariness of the ruler and the terror of the Imbonerakure militia he created. Hundreds of people have already been killed, thousands have been imprisoned, and 300,000 have fled to neighboring countries. Freedom of expression is suppressed and freedom of the press is abolished. There is a risk of a resurgence of the civil war that ended twelve years ago. That is why I also think it is urgent that we deal with the situation there. It is regrettable, however, that we have so far not been able to formulate a joint resolution on this with our African partners in the ACP-EU Assembly. We must make it clear to them that our aim is not to interfere in the internal affairs of an African country, but that we are concerned about stability in the region, the fate of many hundreds of thousands of people and the observance of civil and human rights.

name: Mariya Gabriel
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, it is our duty to strengthen the actions of the European Union in Burundi. I will focus on two aspects: human rights and the regional context. Yes, ten days ago, the Iteka League was struck off the list of NGOs authorized to work in the country for its denunciations of human rights violations and the risk of genocide. This decision comes on top of others targeting international NGOs which denounce the deterioration of the situation in Burundi and send a signal of radicalization of the government. We must protect human rights defenders, international NGOs and Burundian civil society. And, in this sense, I call for the adoption of an urgent plan to normalize the situation of human rights and fundamental freedoms. Secondly, we cannot leave aside the regional context, which is deteriorating day by day. Growing political instability in East Africa is deepening the humanitarian crisis and insecurity. It is imperative that the Union work more closely - but above all with clearly defined responsibilities - with the African Union, the East African Community and all the international partners for the resumption of an inter-Burundian dialogue. in order to find a quick and concerted solution to the crisis the country is going through.

name: David Martin
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, in July 2015 I was the EU’s chief observer for the Presidential elections in Burundi. Within days of arriving in the country, I concluded that the conditions for fair elections did not exist and that the media, the opposition and NGOs were all being intimidated and harassed. The situation then was grim.  Since then, I’m sad to say, Burundi has descended into total lawlessness. Burundi’s once vibrant media has been decimated, the ruling party’s Youth Movement murder, torture, rape and extort money and possessions with complete impunity. With the media silenced, the opposition decimated and the judiciary corrupt, ordinary Burundians have no one to speak for them. They have no voice or protection in their own country, so others must speak for them.  I welcome the EU’s decision to extend our suspension of direct economic support and our restrictive measures against key figures, but we must be prepared to do more and we must encourage Burundi’s African neighbours to take on board their responsibilities.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Madam President, first of all, as you did not want to give me the floor and I will not be too long, I wanted to particularly support President Michel and my colleague Kyenge for their interventions on the Central African Republic. I believe that their words are part of common sense, intelligence of a situation and the transition that we must support with the new Central African president. Regarding Burundi, this country is a concentrate of the woes of Africa and, it must be said, of the crisis in the Great Lakes region. The misfortune of the lack of development due to the weakness of States, the misfortune of the tribalization of power, encouraged, it must be said, by foreign companies and States, the misfortune of a region where interference and massacres follow one another . What we must do for this Great Lakes region, but also for the Lake Chad area, is to put in place a real Marshall Plan combining security and development. Without security, no development. Without development, there is no security.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, ós rud é gurb é seo mo chéad óráid san athbhliain tá mé chun é a dhéanamh i mo theanga dhúchais féin. Is trua gur ábhar míshásúil atá idir lámha againn ach tá súil agam go n-éireoidh linn tríd an rún seo rudaí a fheabhsú sa Bhurúin. Agus tá rudaí imithe ar gcúl go háirithe ó shocraigh uachtarán na tíre dul ar aghaidh don triú téarma i gcoinne a bhunreacht féin. Meastar go bhfuil míle duine curtha chun báis ó shin, go bhfuil daoine ag teitheadh na tíre, go bhfuil cearta daonna á séanadh, go bhfuil coir agus caimiléireacht de gach saghas ar siúl agus go bhfuil 4.6 milliún duine i mbaol ocrais. Dá bhrí sin, is uafásach an scéal é mar a dúirt na feisirí eile agus tá súil agam go n-éireoidh linn brú a chur ar an uachtarán chun an deachtóireacht uafásach seo a stopadh sa Bhurúin.

name: Maria Arena (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Burundi, on the arrival of Nkurunziza and even before his arrival, presents a dramatic situation. President Nkurunziza also announces that he could possibly run for a fourth term. The third does not satisfy him and the fact that he has plunged his country into instability and uncertainty does not satisfy him either. He would like to continue with a fourth term. He takes Burundi out of the International Court, plunges his country into poverty and instability and risks the explosion of an ethnic approach within Burundi. Today our relationship with him presents serious difficulties. We know that there are negotiations, mediations with the Burundian government. We are asking to be able to maintain sanctions against this government. We ask that there can also be targeted sanctions and we ask that there be work on the part of the Burundian authorities. A dialogue could be established, but under the current conditions, in the absence of democracy, given the fact that journalists, lawyers and all those who speak out against Burundi can no longer speak, it has become impossible for we, Europeans, to continue to dialogue with this country.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - It is a fact that President Burundi does not abide by the agreed agreements, he even resigned from the statute of the International Criminal Court.He is committing genocide, he is repressing his people, I think it is necessary to send a clear message to President Burundi that even if he moves to the moon, his actions will be subject to retrospective review and, at the very least, he will be criminally liable.I think it is important that we send a message here today to those people in Burundi who are seeking its democratic revival, that our aid will be targeted, that we will insist on sanctions against this regime and that we will support those who are in this regime today.prosecuted.That, I think, should be the basic message from today's sitting, otherwise, of course, I support the draft report that has been tabled.

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge (S&D).
text: - Madam President, since the passage in force for a new unconstitutional mandate contrary to the Arusha accords, President Pierre Nkurunziza and his regime have redoubled their efforts in applying the policy of arbitrariness. This is reflected in the arbitrary shutdown of human rights organizations, including the Iteka League, and in targeted attacks and assassinations against politicians, journalists and the general public. Recently, three people were removed from the Bar Association and one person suspended for one year, in total violation of lawyers' freedom of expression and the autonomy of the judiciary. Faced with this state of affairs, we have suspended funding and applied targeted sanctions with regard to the regime in place in Bujumbura. But, if the regime continues to disrespect its people, the European Union will have to take more binding measures against Burundian political leaders.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all, I am very grateful to those colleagues who have kept Burundi high on the agenda of this House. Burundi remains of great concern. Since 2015 we have witnessed a sharp rise in political violence linked to the electoral process, which led to a contested third mandate for the president. We are confronted with widespread impunity, high levels of armed incidents, extra—judicial killings and abductions as well as cases of torture by the police and the intelligence service. Government officials are reducing the political space, the freedom of the media and of association, and are publicly indulging in hate speech. There is no disarming of militias and no significant return of the more than 533 000 refugees who have fled the country.  In sum: we are still a long way from addressing the causes of this crisis which are manifest in the corrosion of the political, security and governance environment.  Against this backdrop, the European Union has suspended financial support to the Burundian administration, including budget support. But let me take the opportunity to underline again that we maintain direct support to the population – supporting health, nutrition, agriculture, energy and humanitarian assistance in the region.  As you know, this decision under Article 96 of the Cotonou Agreement coincided with individual sanctions against persons undermining democracy or obstructing the search for a political solution, including by acts of violence, repression and inciting violence. Those responsible for human rights violations and violence – regardless of their political persuasion – cannot escape personal responsibility for their actions.  The position of the government appears to be hardening, including the decisions: to stop cooperating with the office of the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights; to withdraw from the Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court; to recall the Burundian ambassador in Brussels; and to impose additional restrictions on international NGOs working in Burundi as well as to withdraw the license of such important national NGOs as the famous ITEKA which has been following the human rights situation for more than 20 years. There are further disturbing developments, such as the President’s announcement to possibly envisage even a fourth term in 2020, in as much as the indications are that the authorities are preparing for a change in the constitution, possibly including the abandoning of the Arusha Principles which have served the country so well in recent years.  The confrontational stance of the government puts particular emphasis on African-led processes, and especially the dialogue facilitated by President Mkapa on behalf of the Eastern African Community. In January in Arusha we saw the resumption of this consultation process. Crucial questions concerning an inclusive Burundian dialogue have been raised – but it was not possible to bridge important gaps to major Burundian opposition groups. There are additional consultations ongoing, including with the government, from 18 to 20 January. The European Union remains fully committed to contribute solving the Burundian crisis, through our bilateral cooperation, at regional level and in cooperation with the African Union and the United Nations. The next assessment of progress made in the Article 96 context is due in spring 2017. At the same time, the Commission services are planning for substantial direct support of the population, as we did in 2016.  The Burundian drama will stay with us for some time to come. We need principled and steadfast action in support of African-led mediation and possible new UN initiatives.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: Thank you very much, Commissioner.I really deserve applause from my fellow Members.I have listened extremely carefully and I apologize for my fellow Members coming to the polls so loudly.I close the debate.The vote will take place today.(The sitting was suspended)

name: Presidente. –
text: The session resumed. Unfortunately I have to inform the Assembly that, following the numerous earthquakes that hit Italy, an avalanche submerged a hotel, there are thirty missing, including children, with a very bad weather situation, the Alpine Rescue of the Guardia di Finanza he reached the hotel after six hours of walking because all the roads were blocked. So on skis the soldiers of the Guardia di Finanza have reached the place and are now trying, with the avalanche dogs, to see if the missing, as we all hope, have survived. Two people have been saved, but the situation is certainly not the best. The population is exhausted. From yesterday at midnight to this morning at six there were eighty earthquakes. Citizens are terrified, the weather situation is very bad, so I believe that on behalf of the whole Parliament we can send a message of solidarity to these European citizens who are experiencing dramatic moments. And I will do everything, I believe with your full consent, so that the European Commission can speed up the timeframe for disbursing the Solidarity Fund with our support, because, I repeat, the situation, my Italian colleagues know, is truly disastrous. Newspapers around the world are talking about what happened. The earthquake caused an avalanche and the avalanche submerged a hotel and they are all under the avalanche, the hotel is under the avalanche. This is the dramatic situation. I spoke a little while ago with the general commander of the Guardia di Finanza, I thanked him for the work these experts have done, six hours of walking is a long time, but we hope they will be able to find the missing alive. I thank everyone again, President Juncker, the Commissioner for the closeness expressed, I believe that we will have to do everything to give concrete answers to these citizens. As the president of the Civil Protection asked me Italian, above all ask for solidarity, because living with hundreds of shocks - there have been hundreds of shocks in recent days - is certainly not easy.So I thank you as an Italian, but above all as the President of Parliament for the solidarity you want to send to these compatriots of ours.Thank you.Mr Valenciano asked to speak.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D).
text: - Mr President, all our solidarity and affection and all the strength that is necessary for the Italian victims.But, since Commissioner Stylianides is here and we also know that there are hundreds of thousands of refugees also in an almost impossible situation due to this cold wave, I also demand solidarity and help for these refugees.

name: Rosa D'Amato (EFDD).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in addition to solidarity there was, in the last plenary session, a motion for a resolution on the earthquake, which the Commission must seriously consider.There were very specific requests that the majority of the European Parliament approved, so let's also turn to the facts.We must certainly do solidarity, we must give it, but concrete acts are needed because the situation will not improve and it is not some citizens who are in poor condition, but it is the vast majority of the population of central Italy.

name: Presidente. –
text: President Juncker already said yesterday that he will do everything possible, I will call him again today, but I believe that we have made our voices heard clearly so that not only the applause can be made, but also concrete things.

name: Ελένη Θεοχάρους (
text: ECR). - Mr President, on behalf of the people of Cyprus, I also express my support for the people of Italy under trial. I will talk to you about a man-made disaster that happened 43 years ago and continues to torment the people of Cyprus. I am very sorry to have to speak before the House, but I must inform you that it was forbidden in my office to organize a photo exhibition from occupied Nicosia, from the ceasefire line called "frozen Nicosia", and the reason is that,'s supposedly, we are at a critical stage for the talks which will be influenced by a photo exhibition to be held inside the European Parliament. And I tell you, Mr President, firstly, that we are not in the radius of an agreement, secondly, if there is an agreement, it will not be compatible with the European acquis and the members will reject it, and thirdly, Erdogan's inflammatory statements further damage the talks. from a report. I'm sorry, but that gives me the impression that we are cooperating in other situations.

name: Presidente. –
text: We must not open a debate on this, we will check, I will ask the Quaestors to give me an answer.Honorable Forenza, you had asked to speak.

name: Eleonora Forenza (GUE/NGL).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe your announcement was important with respect to the situation in central Italy.There are thousands of European citizens who are struggling to find normality.I believe it is essential that the security of European citizens is interpreted, first of all, as the security of one's own territory, with respect to one's own homes and that this is a reward with respect to the logic of stability.I also allow myself to testify our solidarity, of this whole Chamber and this group, to those populations and to warmly thank all the active solidarity brigades who are bringing relief in these hours in a disastrous situation due to the earthquake and snow..

name: Presidente. –
text: During the Conference of Presidents, we decided to emphasize the Chamber and also emphasize current affairs.I pointed out what happened in a country of the European Union, so I believe that I will be swift in voting.However, we also respect what has happened and the sentiment of the representatives of the Italian people who sit in this Chamber.We are not bureaucrats, we are representatives of the European peoples and when there is a European people suffering, we must be close to the European people, it is not a question of voting sooner or later.I will be quick in voting.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, I would like to congratulate you on your appointment, and certainly your stance on Italy right at this moment. On a point of order under Rule 15(1), could I ask you to look at the future election voting system that we have just incurred this week, where it says the President should be elected by secret ballot. I have no objection to this, but why are we going backwards in time by using paper ballot votes that took a whole day to process under enormous cost to the taxpayer? Yet, within this Chamber, we have the facility to process secret electronic votes. I believe in future you should encourage this Chamber to avoid wasting time and taxpayers’ money by moving for a better process.

name: Presidente. –
text: Thank you honorable. We have already voted for the Quaestors with this system. Yesterday, Mr Lavrilleux said during the discussion on the conclusions of the European Council meeting on 15 December that Mr Lundgren would have made a racist phrase during his speech. Mr Lundgren denied having uttered that sentence. As I promised you yesterday, I asked to have the transcription and translation of the interventions before making any decision on this matter. Having read the translation and the intervention in the original text in Mr Lundgren's mother tongue and the recording of the French interpretation, I can confirm that it was a misunderstanding due to an error of interpretation. Mr Lundgren did not utter any racist remarks during her speech. I must publicly acknowledge this and I apologize if there has been an error; each of us can make a mistake, but the word could have been interpreted differently, so we must acknowledge Mr Lundgren that he did not utter any racist phrases and I also thank Mr Lavrilleux who received an interpretation in the French language translation instead (…). I have promised this House to guarantee the right to speak to all Members. We will have the vote quickly, but as the accusation against Mr Lundgren was serious, I wanted to ascertain the truth and as he did not utter any racist remarks, the whole House had to be made aware of them. Mr Lavrilleux rightly denounced what had happened in the French interpretation.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is voting time.(For the results of the votes and other details concerning them: see Minutes)

name: Presidente. –
text: Appointments for the composition of parliamentary committees.The nomination proposals for the composition of the parliamentary committees presented to the Conference of Presidents were communicated to the Chamber yesterday.I inform you that the ECR Group has asked to replace Mr Tannock with Mr Bashir as a member of the Subcommittee on Human Rights.I therefore declare the appointments approved with this amendment.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: We now turn to the explanations of vote.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - I will try to explain in the noise why I supported this report.In my opinion, this report can contribute to the development of transport infrastructure within the EU, and if we are building an internal market, then the internal market can hardly function without quality infrastructure.In short and well, if we are talking here, for example, about the digital sale of goods on the Internet as one of the Commission's priorities for this term, then the sale of goods will not work unless there is sufficient quality transport infrastructure to import and export goods across borders.Member States.So I welcome the report, I supported it, I wish it would contribute to the development of transport infrastructure.A certain disadvantage of this report is that it is very general and that it does not contain any commitments that should lead to both the EU and individual Member States spending more money on transport infrastructure development in the future.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, speed, sustainability, efficiency are the keywords for organizing the flow of goods and information from their point of origin to their destination. Europe means breaking down borders, the more difficult it seems to break down distances, reduce travel times, organize travel. I voted in favor of this report because the construction of Europe is concretely expressed in logistics. It is logistics that makes Europe move, no one has time to wait anymore, freight transport must be faster and more efficient, logistics today employs over 11 million people, by 2040, in little more in twenty years, the sector will grow by 40 percent. It is important to develop the central TEN-T corridors but also and above all the more widespread global network that allows goods to arrive at their final destination. It is on the last stretch that we must insist, we must work where it is more complicated. The real challenge of European logistics is the regions, like mine, Sicily, insular and remote with poor infrastructures.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - I supported this proposal because I consider smoothly functioning logistics and interconnected infrastructure to be very important for regional development and economic growth in the EU in general.I think the importance of freight transport is very fundamentally illustrated by the fact that the sector employs more than 11 million people in all EU Member States.That is why I consider it very important that such reports be submitted to the plenary in order to further develop the sector, but at the same time I also want to make the reports somewhat more specific and not just general statements.One of the more specific statements why I also supported the report was the mention of independent scientific studies which will examine, among other things, the impact of transport on the environment and the means by which air pollution could be reduced.So I would like to continue in this direction.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Madam President, in transport, as in other areas, policy tends to be constantly playing catch—up with technology. Next time you’re standing at a busy junction, count how many people are driving for a living, one way or another – bus drivers, van drivers, Uber drivers, black cab drivers and delivery men – and then ponder the thought that, in 10 or 15 years, almost all those jobs will be redundant – replaced by driverless cars or drones. A lot of people find that a very frightening prospect, and yet we’ve heard the same argument with every new technology. When the industrial revolution happened, there was a constant backlash of people saying that the only real jobs were on the land, and that there would never be enough factory jobs to support all those people; when the economy was moved from industry to service, exactly the same arguments were made: that there wouldn’t be enough jobs cutting each other’s hair and flipping burgers. But what those arguments miss is that when you free up time through technological innovation, people are liberated to create whole new industries that nobody dreamed of. Who saw these things coming 15 years ago? There will be more jobs than ever.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I commend this report’s thorough consideration of the process of planning, managing and achieving an efficient and sustainable flow of goods and information throughout the EU. The full realisation of such logistics may foster the smooth functioning and enhancement of the internal market, whilst contributing to European GDP, growth, employment and competitiveness. In bolstering existing and future strategies, we may achieve a more sustainable European framework of mobility across all networks, and in light of evolving economic, societal and technological trends. These efforts will have an immeasurable effect on the day—to—day lives of Europeans, furthering our goals of harmonisation, whilst realising the renewed potential of the free movement of persons, goods and services across Member States. I therefore support this report and voted for it, according to my colleagues’ in the EPP’s line.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - In the final vote, I could not support the resolution on the European Pillar of Social Rights.I voted in favor of those proposals which sought to adapt this report so as not to interfere with the subsidiarity and powers of the Member States.I am in favor of sound social policy, for guaranteeing social rights at European level, but not for interfering in the rights of the Member States.The EP resolution goes beyond this in this regard.I am glad that we managed to delete the requirement to introduce a minimum wage in the vote, but unfortunately other amendments have not been adopted and I consider the proposal, such as the EU child guarantee, to be really unrealistic.Therefore, I could not support the resolution as a whole.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - I also did not support this proposal. I do not think that the issue of social policy should be a key issue on the European agenda. Of course, as a modern politician, I perceive social policy as an important part of the state's activities, but in my opinion, according to the principle of subsidiarity, social policy should remain primarily at the level of individual member states. The proposal we have adopted goes far beyond and takes away the competences of individual nation states and seeks to create a European, say, central social policy. The requirement to introduce a minimum wage, the requirements to introduce different types of parental leave, including maternity, paternity, caring, etc., are things that individual Member States should adapt to their economic strength, their history, their tradition, but we should not we dictate from Brussels to individual nation states. That is why I consider this proposal to be bad and I did not support it.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, almost two years ago we all warmly welcomed the words of President Juncker who supported the European Pillar of Social Rights. I voted in favor of this report because we really need a European social system that establishes clear and precise rights for all European workers. We need a tool capable of changing and improving the lives of citizens: a job without rights, in a Europe where there is very little work, is a job that is almost always based on blackmail. Labor without rights is a mere bargaining chip. If this Europe, so much in question, wants to grow, now is the time to do so, because there is no economic growth without social growth. In our Europe there is no work without workers' rights. I think of the many, too many workers who die from lack of security and of the women and men forced to give up their private life in order not to lose their profession. And so this Europe really needs the pillar of social rights, indeed, more than a pillar, I would say, it needs a strong base on which to build the growth of the new Europe.

name: Diane James (NI).
text: – Madam President, I am an independent MEP, and I am not affiliated to any political group. I supported the ENF proposed amendment today and I want to explain why. The ENF proposal and their amendment highlighted the detrimental effect of the single currency and the harmful EU policies which resulted in increasing unemployment and poverty across the continent. It also highlighted that employment and social policy initiatives should be Member State competences, which actually is a very important perspective; equally, that only national governments can truly effect the financing of changes in these areas to deliver results; and the amendment also stressed the need for Member States to take responsibility to achieve economic and social recovery. Finally, the amendment criticised the EU’s blame-game policy, casting blame rather than acknowledging that fault actually lies with the EU itself.  Now I may not support the ENF politically, but today they submitted an objective and valid amendment which I was happy to support.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: - I supported Mr Rodriguez's report on the European Pillar of Social Rights. The proposals contained in it are important and contribute to the exchange of good practices to address the challenges. Without belittling the fact that the main competence in the field of social and labor policy and legislation lies with the Member States of the European Union, I would like to point out that Europe needs a new model to follow. A model based on the interests of European citizens. A model that focuses on the real problems of the Union and their solutions. Europe must be able to cope with the progress and development of technologies, which in turn have contributed to the creation of new working conditions and to the requirement for quality and adequate education. There are no universal solutions, but the challenges facing member states are often similar. Despite its focus on the euro area, the important thing is that the European Pillar of Social Rights will be open to all countries that want to join it.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - I could not support this draft report for many reasons.First, in general, I think that it is a certain wealth or strength of society that should then indicate whether it can afford a certain level of social protection of rights.The EU, although generally considered to be an area where wealth is relatively clearly defined and measurable, on the other hand, has very clear differences in its area, and for this reason too it would be far more appropriate to leave this level of social rights to the Member States.I also could not agree with the effort to create a European framework for unemployment or minimum income support or with the effort to strengthen the first pension pillar at the expense of the others.There are a number of contentious issues in the report that have not been sufficiently clarified, and for these reasons I have not been able to support this report, even for violating the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Madam President, after the UK’s departure from the European Union the other Member States will be much freer to push ahead with the harmonisation of social policy, which I’m sure will be a matter of relief to many Members in this House. It will no longer be our responsibility, but of course we will still have a continuing interest in the success and stability of our neighbours. Prosperous neighbours make good customers, and we are talking about countries which are old friends and allies. One of the things that I have found quoted at me many times since I was elected nearly 20 years ago is Winston Churchill’s speech in Zurich in 1946 when he said: ‘I am going to say something which will astonish you. I want a United States of Europe’. Nobody ever quotes what he went on to say; he made it clear that Britain would not be part of that the United States of Europe, but would support it from the outside as a flying buttress, as a friend and a sponsor. Now we have the opportunity, belatedly, to realise his vision: to have a relationship with our European friends that is based on cooperation rather than convergence, on alliance rather than absorption.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: –  Madam President, I appreciate that the European pillar of social rights is a central facet of the Commission’s efforts to move toward a deeper, fairer and more harmonised economic and monetary union. However, in line with my colleagues in the EPP, I remain cautious of certain proposals within this report, including, but not limited to: definitions of ‘worker’; certain framework directives and financial instruments outlined; as well as calls for a binding EPSR and proposals in the sphere of social and educational investments.  In line with my Group I voted in favour of this report, as such concerns were somewhat abated and because it is important to have social rights in mind in all policy making. However, I would urge that our EPP’s recommendations be seriously considered and that further dialogue may be facilitated as we lay the grounds for a European pillar of social rights catering to the needs of all Member States and all their citizens.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution on visa handling related to the implementation of the Union Customs Code because I support the efforts to achieve harmonization of the procedural rules of the customs administrations of the individual Member States.I consider this necessary to achieve the goal of the customs union, which is, above all, a common EU approach towards third countries in collecting customs duties and controlling the entry of goods from third countries into the EU market.I also welcome this initiative to strengthen cooperation between the customs administrations of the individual Member States, as well as the full electronicisation of customs systems, which I consider essential in modern times.I also consider it necessary to reduce the administrative burden, which is an obstacle, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises.Unlike European regulation of social rights, this process of harmonization is appropriate.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - I will be very brief, I supported this material because, within the customs union, care must be taken to ensure that communication between the customs authorities of the individual Member States is as efficient as possible.This material takes into account what has already been adopted and started last year, ie.that the individual customs authorities should communicate electronically and from 2020 that communication should be 100% completely electronic.This report, which is linked to this communication change, is, in my view, correct, it obliges the Commission to monitor the whole process and to inform the EP of the results.This legislation will clearly lead to faster and better functioning within the customs union.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - I also supported this proposal because it responds to a problem that is really serious.By this I mean the customs rules and procedures in the context of customs procedures, which are very complex and particularly small and medium-sized enterprises.Their simplification, elimination of administrative burdens and electronicisation are therefore highly desirable, as this report calls for.I would also like to emphasize that the customs union is a cornerstone of the EU, and its effective setting is therefore important for the proper functioning of the internal market that we are striving for here.For these reasons, too, I very much welcome similar reports that aim to improve, make the basic building blocks and pillars on which the EU is built more efficient, and that is where the customs union definitely belongs.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Madam President, a number of members yesterday were questioning what the British Prime Minister had meant when she said she wanted some continuing aspects of the Customs Union to remain in force. Actually if you read her words it was pretty clear. We are very determined – she is very determined – to leave the common commercial policy and to have the freedom to negotiate bilateral trade deals with America and Australia and India and China and so on, but there may be technical aspects of the Customs Union which would survive if they were in the interests of all parties – for example, the rules that obviate the need for veterinary checks at every border. If all sides wanted those things to continue then of course it would be silly to make an ideological point out of sacrificing pragmatism to dogma. As I have said on many occasions in this Chamber you will be losing a bad tenant, but I hope you will be gaining a good neighbour.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I was pleased to vote in favour of this report on the challenges of implementing the Union Customs Code (UCC). The UCC builds on existing concepts to streamline the customs processes and procedures across the Customs Union, clarifying the rules on release for free circulation and on special procedures.  Effective customs cooperation in the EU and with third countries is crucial, given the significant trade volumes and the challenges for the Customs Union since its creation. I welcome the report’s call for a timeline and for a clear strategy to ensure necessary elements are introduced for the EU customs systems. I also welcome the call on the Commission to rectify any legal shortcomings that may be hindering trade. The proper implementation of the UCC is important for the EU to function as one of the largest trading blocs in the world and I am sure that such strategic cooperation may be an aspect that, despite what my good friend Mr Hannan says, the British may regret when they leave the European Union.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: That concludes the explanations of vote.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission statement on building a European data economy (2017/2505 (RSP)).

name: Marianne Thyssen
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, on 10 January, the Commission presented one of the last Digital Single Market Initiatives addressing Europe’s Digital Future, which concerns data. With the adoption of the communication on building the European Data Economy, the Commission launched a public consultation. Data has become an essential resource for economic growth and social progress. In the near future, most economic activity will depend on data. The data market is estimated in the European Union at more than EUR 50 billion and models project its growth to EUR 111 billion in 2020. In the Digital Single Market Strategy we committed to tackling restrictions on the free movement of data in the European Union, considered essential for the European Union’s successful transition to Industry 4.0 and a modern data economy. The barriers to the free movement of data in the European Union may arise from legal rules or administrative guidelines or practices that required the storage or processing of data to be limited to a particular geographical area or jurisdiction. The trend, both globally and in Europe, is towards more data localisation, an approach often based on the misconception that localised services are automatically safer than cross—border services. This could inhibit data—driven businesses, particularly start—ups and SMEs, from scaling up their activities or entering new markets, but it could also block access for businesses and public sector organisations to cheaper and more innovative data services. The Commission wants to ensure that Europe’s fundamental freedoms concerning the movement of services and establishment are also respected when it comes to data services. The principle of free movement of personal data based services is enshrined in European Union primary and secondary law. Any Member State’s action affecting data storage or processing should be guided by a principle of free movement of data within the EU in line with their obligations under the free movement of services and the free establishment provisions of the Treaty, but also by obligations stemming from relevant secondary legislation.  The current Data Protection Regulation fully regulates the processing of personal data in the European Union, including machine-generated or industrial data when this identifies a natural person. By setting uniform high standards of data protection, the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) ensures the free flow of personal data in the European Union. In this context, as announced in the communication, the Commission will soon enter into structured dialogues with the Member States and other stakeholders on the justification for, and proportionality of, data allocation measures. It will take as a starting point restrictions already identified by the Commission. Following the results of the structured dialogues with Member States and other stakeholders and further evidence gathering via public consultations, the Commission will launch, where needed and appropriate, infringement proceedings to address unjustified or disproportionate data location measures. It will also, if necessary, take further initiatives on the free flow of data.  The communication also addresses other aspects of the data economy such as data ownership, data transfer and liability issues, for example who owns data, how it can be exploited and where responsibility should lie if an automatic device makes the wrong choice. These are essential issues to clarify for a working data economy. This part of the communication further examines issues connected with access to data and how more data can become available for use and reuse. Large—scale trading, sharing or exchange of data, is unfortunately rare today in the European Union.  Finally, we need to look into improving the portability of business data. For example, a company cannot yet easily switch its data between cloud service providers. Portability can lower costs and increase trust and therefore also lower entry barriers for innovative ideas.  In the communication, the Commission makes it clear that more information is needed on the above areas. To this end we have launched two public consultations and will enter into structured dialogues with the Member States and other stakeholders to seek out workable solutions. Following the results of the dialogues and the further evidence-gathering, these solutions may include guidance, benchmarks, model contracts or other new initiatives if these are deemed necessary. Our overall objective is to remove barriers and support data economy developments. Indeed, the more the data available is used and flows freely, the better the data economy will develop and help to create growth and jobs.  On 10 January, the Commission also adopted its proposal for a regulation on privacy and electronic communications after a year-long review of the e—Privacy Directive. If we want to make the most of data, people must feel confident that their data is protected. This is why the Commission is proposing new rules on privacy and the protection of personal data in electronic communications. The measures aim to update the current rules, extending their scope to all electronic communication providers. They also aim to create new possibilities to process communication data and reinforce trust and security in the digital single market, which is a key objective of the Digital Single Market Strategy. A major objective of the review is to align the rules for electronic communications with the new world-class standards of the European Union’s General Data Protection Regulation.  As you know, Europeans are concerned about their privacy. Electronic communications can reveal highly sensitive information about a person or a business. In a recent Eurobarometer survey, 92% of respondents say it is important, or very important, that personal information on their computer, smartphone or tablet can only be accessed with their permission. 92% also state that it is important – or again very important – that the confidentiality of their emails and online instant messaging is guaranteed. The proposed regulations on privacy and electronic communications seek to address those concerns. At the same time, the new rules will support innovation and increase consumer trust in electronic communication services essential for the digital single market to flourish. The proposed regulation will increase the protection of people’s private lives and open up new opportunities for business by taking the following four measures. First of all, the Commission proposes an extension of the scope to include providers of electronic communication services such as WhatsApp, Facebook Messenger, Skype, Gmail, iMessage and Viber. Secondly, the confidentiality of communications’ content and metadata remain the core of the legal instrument. So privacy will be guaranteed for both content and metadata derived from electronic communications, for example the time and duration of a call and location. Thirdly, the proposal provides for new business opportunities. Once consent is given for communications data to be processed, traditional telecom operators will have more opportunities to use data and provide additional services. Finally, simpler rules on cookies are needed. Therefore the so—called Cookie Provision, which has resulted in an overload of consent requests for internet users, will be streamlined. New rules will allow users to be more in control of their settings, providing an easy way to accept or refuse the tracking of cookies and other identifiers in case of privacy risks. The Commission believes that the extensive consultation of stakeholders, better regulation evaluation and the impact assessment resulted in a balanced and technologically neutral proposal fit for the digital age. Finally, on 10 January the Commission presented new rules to ensure that, when personal data are handled by European institutions and bodies, privacy is protected in the same way as it is in Member States under the General Data Protection Regulation. The Commission also presented a strategic framework for international personal data transfers where it reiterated its commitment to encouraging data transfers with our partners, businesses or companies based on high personal data protection standards.  The EU is a world leader on data protection rules and we serve as an inspiration for many third countries. Those with whom we have very close economic ties are interested in adequacy findings – this is particularly the case for Japan and South Korea – and we will engage with them. Our aim is to promote high data protection standards internationally.

name: Andreas Schwab
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. -  Mister President! First of all, I would like to take this opportunity to congratulate you on your convincing re-election. I look forward to meeting you frequently with you here in this house for the next two and a half years. Secondly, I am pleased that Commissioner Thyssen, who was once a member of the European Parliament's Internal Market Committee, is presenting this important legislative package to the European Commission on the data economy today. Thank you very much for that. The package is so broad and large that I only want to concentrate on one aspect: the aspect that Günter Oettinger, the outgoing Commissioner who is now responsible for the budget, has presented here. I think this is really a very comprehensive package that puts the right focus on the essential questions of the data economy and basically addresses these questions, and above all seeks an answer to the question of the ownership of data in the digital age. Because one thing is clear: many consumer issues have been addressed. We can find solutions for this. But the great uncertainty that many medium-sized and smaller companies face is that they do not know how to open up to the digital economy on the one hand and how to ensure that the data is appropriately secure and protected on the other are. On the one hand, there are of course the requirements of the network and information security guidelines, which urgently need to be implemented because we have to fight against cyber attacks and for more cyber security not only on the part of the state, but also on the private sector. But of course there is also the question of what incentives the legislature sets for sharing data. The best example is always the question of which data in the car can ultimately be assigned to which service provider. And this question, Mrs Thyssen - you have to put it that way - is not finally clarified with the proposal.It is also an incredibly difficult question politically and economically.If we do not succeed in creating incentives so that the data that is available is actually used by all providers in the market who are interested in it, then we will not be able to provide the European data economy with the impetus that is urgentnecessary is.Secondly, I think it is very positive that the Commission is expressly addressing the so-called lock-in effect in this proposal - an effect that has played a role in competition proceedings, but has so far played no role in legislation.

name: Andrejs Mamikins
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, digital data is an essential resource for economic growth, competitiveness, innovation, job creation and social progress in general. The EU needs to ensure that data flows across borders and sectors. This data should be accessible by most stakeholders in an optimal way. A coordinated European approach is essential for the development of the data economy. I think that it is very important that the Commission has launched a public consultation and dialogue with stakeholders on these topics. This process will help identify future policy or legislative measures that will unleash Europe’s data economy.  The value of the EU data economy was estimated at EUR 272 billion in 2015, or almost 2% of  EU GDP. If the policy and legal framework conditions for the data economy are put in place in time, its value will increase to EUR 643 billion by 2020, representing more than 3% of overall EU GDP. The General Data Protection Regulation will be one single European set of rules, as opposed to 28 national laws today. The newly created one-stop shop mechanism will ensure that one data protection authority will be responsible for the supervision of cross-border data processing operations carried out by a company in the European Union.  To build the data economy the EU needs a policy framework that enables data to be used throughout the value chain for scientific, social and industrial purposes. The Commission should launch a wide-ranging stakeholder dialogue on the issues of building a European data economy. The first step in this dialogue will be a public consultation. The issue of data access and liability should be tested in a real-life environment in the field of cooperative, connected and automated mobility. Concerning to the free flow of data, the Commission has to continue to work to fully implement the principle of the free flow of data within the EU. The Commission has to continue also to monitor and gather evidence, and if necessary consider taking further initiatives on the free flow of data.

name: Dita Charanzová
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. –  Mr President, the ALDE Group read the Data Economy package from last week with great interest and hope. I have to say that there is one important item missing in your package. Where is the ban on localisation requirements within the EU? Where is the ban, Madam Commissioner? It is wrong to allow Member States to force companies to hold data in one Member State instead of another Member State. All Member States are equal. All European data is governed by the same set of principles and the same data protection rules. That is why we have adopted a General Data Protection Regulation. A regulation, not a directive. It should not matter if a server is in Helsinki or Lisbon or Prague. Every European should know that their data is safe, throughout the European Union.  Companies must be free to use digital infrastructure anywhere in Europe. We have seen a number of countries outside the European Union adopting data localisation laws for both economic and anti-democratic reasons: to spy, to censor, to demand money from companies. These rules can often endanger citizens more than protect them. The free flow of data must be regarded as the fifth freedom of the Single Market in Europe and the ALDE group therefore says ‘no’ to data localisation laws. You have rightly said that you want to remove the barriers in the digital single market. Yes, I agree, we want a fully functioning digital single market, but data localisation is a barrier to making it happen.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, congratulations on your re—election and also congratulations to Mrs Thyssen on a very good presentation to us here today. There is no doubt about it: a thriving digital economy is one of the cornerstones of growth and employment in the EU. However, as has been outlined by the Commissioner, barriers remain that prevent us from achieving the full potential of the digital economy. Europe’s digital market, for example, remains heavily fragmented. This is a key part of the European digital single market strategy which could add EUR 415 billion per annum to the EU economy, creating an additional income of EUR 817 per person. The digital economy is estimated to represent 22.5% of the world economy and is estimated to be worth 8.4 billion or 5% of GDP in my own country of Ireland. That is an 85% increase between 2009 and 2014. So completing the digital single market is vital for all of us.  Because of that, we must look at the barriers and here our competitiveness is at stake. Ensuring the free flow of data in the EU is simply crucial if we in Europe want to keep pace with Asia and North America. Data localisation rules in different Member States inhibit growth and are a barrier to this investment. In order to complete and implement the European digital single market and enable international data flows that support innovation securely, removing existing data localisation measures will drive down the cost of data services while expanding their use and choice. This alone could boost GDP by up to EUR 8 billion per year.  So, we have a lot of work to do, especially in the following areas: supervisory authorities obliging financial services providers to store their data locally; professional secrecy rules, for example in the health sector, implying local data storage and processing; sweeping regulations requiring the local storage of archived information generated by the public sector whatever its sensitivity.  Finally, I would just like to say I had the pleasure of working on the Data Protection Regulation and now I look forward to working with what is not covered in that – that is non-personal data.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: - Mr. Chairman, first of all I congratulate you on your election and I immediately emphasize how big, huge the new European data market is. It is a great new opportunity, a new chance for our economy, but it also demands our new responsibility. First of all, I want to clearly emphasize that we need a series of clearly specified, but also simplified rules and legal regulations that will solve problems in terms of data ownership, data portability, data availability, research and innovation in the data economy, personal data protection, data localization, what we’ve already talked about, and of course align it all along with the digital single market. The other thing I want to emphasize is the need for partnership, the European Union's partnership with member states, but let's never forget regional and local authorities and of course the private sector, and when we talk about the private sector I don't always mean big companies but small companies. So we have a lot to do, and the partnership, I’m sure, can contribute to making our economy even more efficient and stronger in terms of data.

name: Lambert van Nistelrooij (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I think big data is the fuel for the future, let me say. We know that it will contribute to solving a lot of society’s challenges. In healthcare, for instance, resource efficiency, intelligent transport, etc. Let me make two remarks. Firstly, we need the free movement of data across the borders and to address several legal uncertainties – and Mr Schwab has already spoken about this – preventing companies to treat Europe as a one big market, not as 28 small separate markets. Europe has repeatedly missed the last ten years, taking the leading role in new cloud business models. Let us not allow this to happen again. Secondly, it is of key importance to educate and enable our young people in the business sector. I strongly welcome the Commission’s report for a European Data Science Academy to bridge the skills gap in Europe by designing curricula for data science training and data science education. I am personally active in this approach in the Netherlands. We are helping a Dutch Academy in this field and it has already started in Den Bosch. There is a huge interest for that, not only for technical aspects but also ethical aspects. Finally, there is – as I just said before – a role for the regions and the cities to take up such a kind of initiative, and during the consultation we will come forward with these kind of possibilities close to citizens and their future.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - Colleagues, I welcome this exchange of information in the EP with the Commission on the very subject of building the data economy.As has already been said here, this market has great potential for growth, for employment.I appreciate the Commission's efforts to break down barriers to data collection, dissemination and also trade.This is exactly one that cannot be decided effectively by the Member States alone, but must also work together with the European Commission to build a digital single market.Ensuring privacy in electronic communications must also be the most important and integral part of these measures.That is why I welcome the European Commission's initiative in this area.Skype, G-mail, Facebook, Whatsapp, these are long-term everyday resources that we use, and we must be sure of secure communication in the future.Thank you, Commissioner, for presenting this initiative.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D).
text: - Mr President, the data economy is key to Europe's future development. We are talking about an opportunity we cannot miss, the modernization of our economy and industry, but also the use of the skills we have here in Europe. This transformation of the economy cannot be stopped. We have two possibilities: to be proactive or reactive. Being reactive means legislating on the problems generated by the data economy after it occurs, sometimes going too far and blocking the development of the sector at European level. The most illustrative example is that of large corporations that have become rich using our data. After years, we reacted, but blocked the development of European companies through a too harsh reaction. Therefore, I want to become proactive, to stimulate the development of the data economy through a set of common rules, clear to users, but also accessible to small and medium enterprises. The idea of ​​educational programs is a first step, but we must reach our potential and we must invest especially in cyber and data security. I think we have expertise at European level and I can say that, especially in my country, Romania, we can find specialists.

name: Jozo Radoš (ALDE).
text: - Mr. President, my congratulations on your re-election.Madam Commissioner, in addition to all the benefits of the data economy, I would like to emphasize that the use of this branch would also enable the reduction of state and public administration costs by 15 to 20 percent.There is much room for improvement in the European data economy as the United States, with which we are comparable, has twice as many employees in that branch of the economy and participates with twice the share of total trade in goods and services.So there is a lot of room for progress in the European data economy.Of all the difficulties, I would mention the danger of digital division, the danger that the differences in the development of our regions in the European Union will increase even more, and special attention should be paid to this.But I certainly thank the report and welcome all the measures announced by the Commissioner for the growth of the data economy in Europe.

name: Marianne Thyssen
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I wish to thank the Members of Parliament for their comments and feedback. I took note of all their questions and concerns. As I said in my introduction, we do not have all the answers yet to all those issues. That is why we are engaging in a broad consultation before deciding on possible policy and legal actions. We are looking forward to pursuing collaboration with the European Parliament on these issues. We are very much looking forward to constructive discussions with the European Parliament in the negotiation of the Commission’s legislative proposal on the privacy and data protection of electronic communications. It is important to act swiftly in order to ensure that the date of application of the general data protection regulation and the new e-privacy regulation coincide and is done in a coherent manner.  As announced in the DSM, the Commission’s objective is to create a clear and adapted policy and legal framework for the data economy by removing barriers to the movement of data and addressing legal uncertainties created by new technologies. We do not yet have, as I said, all the answers to the complex issues in front of us, so we will consult extensively. The gathered information will be invaluable in deciding how to best move forward, in particular with respect to the free flow of data.
