text: The debate is closed.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. – Due to the rapid digitalisation of the global economy and the aim of the European Union to be a world leader in this digital economy, the Digital Single Market (DSM) strategy was adopted on the 6 May 2015 to ensure the free movement of goods, persons, services and capital. Building a European data economy is part of the Digital Single Market strategy, which, through the best use of its essential resource, digital data, may deliver innovation, economic growth, job creation and competitiveness in all fields, including in health care where it could improve daily life. Even if access to machine-generated data is under consideration in the health and care sector, the diversity of the data processed by machines for scientific purposes could improve products or create innovative services for patients. As the Commission underlined in its communication, the ‘big data’ sector is growing by 40% per year, seven times faster than the IT market, but all this data need to be protected. Therefore, ensuring a policy framework is more than necessary, and Parliament, together with the Council, should play a fundamental role.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: written. - Digitalization has now reached all areas of our life, and it does not matter whether it is private or professional. Reliable data protection and the highest level of security represent great challenges and, at the same time, enormous economic potential. Digitization harbors challenges for a wide variety of industries, no economic sector seems to be excluded from it. New, innovative business models, especially in the area of ​​SMEs, are being created and represent added value for the economy and society. However, cyber threats and hacker attacks are also increasing and are becoming an enormous threat to critical network infrastructures, such as power supply. We have to take action here in order to be able to guarantee network and information security (NIS). Data protection also plays a central role in terms of competitiveness. Questions such as the protection of trade secrets or data security still need to be clarified more specifically. The fragmentation of individual sectors - such as security, transparency and the locations of users and data - must also be viewed critically. Fragmentation in the data economy is not expedient and should therefore be rejected along with internet censorship and mass surveillance.

name: Karol Karski (ECR)
text: in writing. - In recent years, we have witnessed a new revolution in the economy driven by digital data. On the one hand, collecting and processing data on an unprecedented scale creates many challenges and, at the same time, presents enormous potential for increasing the productivity of the EU economy. However, the development of a data-driven economy requires some kind of action plan if we want to ensure that entrepreneurs and consumers in the European Union take full advantage of the dynamics of the big data sector, which will become a determinant of change for our entire economy. The European Parliament has been calling for a review of possible tools for the development of the data economy for some time and identifies the types of framework needed in the area of ​​regulatory and non-regulatory needs that would be a key element in shaping a better environment for growth in this area. The European digital economy is too slow to take the data revolution compared to the US or even China, for example. It is therefore imperative that European business and consumers fully exploit the benefits of the Big Data sector. It will be a determinant of change for our economy and will bring tangible benefits to Europe in terms of competitiveness, which is so important, not to say breakthrough, in the coming years.

name: Jeppe Kofod (S&D)
text: in writing. - A cornerstone of the development of the European digital agenda is that data can be moved freely. At the same time, it is of course a precondition for free data flows that sensitive personal information is processed perfectly securely and securely, and that EU member states can set necessary restrictions for reasons of national security. This is only ensured through common legislation and common definitions in the EU. ECIPE studies show that huge sums can be released in the European economy if existing blockades are removed. Estimates go all the way up to 8 billion. euros per year (approx. NOK 60 billion). An amount that will be realized in savings for European citizens and businesses. At the same time, we also see a tendency towards more national requirements for data of various kinds to be stored within geographically delimited areas. If this trend continues, the consequence, according to the aforementioned studies, could be a loss for the European economy of up to 52 billion. euros per year (approx. NOK 387 billion). That is why I would like to call on the Commission to put forward proposals for pan-European legislation in this area as soon as possible, so that we can secure the sensitive information of European citizens and businesses in the best possible way, avoid costly special requirements and free up large sums for a European economy in need of investment.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – The four freedoms of the EU single market rely on the free movement of data. However, unjustified data localisation requirements in national public procurement rules and legislation is increasingly fragmenting the single market. Consumers and companies, rather than authorities, should decide where in the EU they want to store their data. In its communication entitled ‘A Digital Single Market Strategy for Europe’ from May 2015, the Commission recognised that ‘unnecessary restrictions regarding the location of data within the EU should both be removed and prevented’. It later promised a European ‘free flow of data’ legislative proposal to tackle restrictions on the free movement of data within the EU and unjustified restrictions on data location. The European Parliament welcomed this initiative in its resolution of January 2016. Despite announcements and wide support from Parliament and the Council, the Commission’s communication on ‘Building a European Data Economy’ falls short of a legislative proposal. It will neither remove any further data protectionism nor prevent it from fragmenting the single market. I strongly encourage the Commission to put forward, without delay, an ambitious legislative proposal to remove and prevent data localisation requirements in the EU single market, for the benefit of European companies and consumers.

name: Algirdas Saudargas (PPE)
text: in writing. - The European Commission's Communication "Building a European Data economy" identifies data as an integral factor in economic growth, job creation and societal progress. The data market in Europe is constantly growing, but still fragmented compared to the US, which is an obstacle to industrial competitiveness. It is essential to strike a balance between data business development models and legal data protection. I support the aim expressed in the Communication of harmonizing legal data protection in the European Union. At the same time, I would like to emphasize that the cyber threats of this era and other related phenomena are no less important. We cannot expect to solve these problems simply by legally defining these issues. The reality today is that technological progress is faster than the rules and legal provisions governing their use. Therefore, the field of data economy must be an area of ​​increased focus in order to strike a balance between rights and obligations.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - In January this year, the EC proposed solutions for the development of the data economy as part of the digital single market strategy. According to her, the EU is not fully exploiting its potential, so restrictions such as localization rules and other technical and legal barriers to the flow of data between Member States and within the Digital Single Space should be removed as soon as possible. Data-based digital products and services can have a major impact on improving environmental protection and food security, energy efficiency and the development of smart transport systems and smart cities. Data analysis improves processes and decisions, encourages innovation and improves predictability. The EU does not have a regulated digital single market for data, as there are obstacles to the free movement of data and many other legal uncertainties, and it has already missed many economic, social and business opportunities. The data economy can only create growth and jobs if we also use the data available to us. Therefore, we need to ensure an adequate flow of data from both a geographical and a cross-sectoral perspective, so that it is more easily accessible and optimally used. A harmonized European approach is essential for the development of the data economy as part of the digital single market, and it is important that we also respect the right to the protection of personal data and privacy.
